activityName: Sunflower oil, at oil mill {GLO} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
"The SALCA process ""Sunflower oil, at oil mill/kg/CH"" is used as a proxy to model Sunflower oil extraction at oil mill. 

Reference flow: Oil Yield_ (unallocated Yield_): 3.31 kg Sunflower seeds are needed for 1 kg Sunflower oil. For Sunflower at farm, the global dataset is used. Sunflower lecithin Yield_s are assumed to be about 0.3% on a seed basis (Nieuwenhuyzen (2014))

Allocation: economic allocation is applied, based on the price ratio between 1 kg oil, 2.3 kg of the co-product Sunflower oil cake and 0.01 kg sunflower lecithin. Price for 1 kg Sunflower oil = 0.72 US $/pound = 1.58 $/kg

activityName: Agaricus bisporus mushroom, fresh, at plant {NL} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of fresh agaricus bisporus mushrooms. 

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes the substrate production, the inoculation with mycellium, the growing chambers disinfection, soil covering (peat), the chambers temperature and humidity control (water and energy consumption) and the growing producess (water and pesticides). The direct emissions from peat are included. 
The infrastructure are excluded as well as the mushroom packaging. The spent substrate is considered to be used in agricultural systems (cut-off). 

Geography: the Netherlands. The main reference used is for Spain but the dataset is adapted to a production in the Netherlands changing the electricity mix and water regionalization. 

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2010-2014

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2, Very good quality

Leiva 2015a: Leiva FJ, Saenz-Díez JC, Martínez E, et al (2015) Environmental impact of Agaricus bisporus cultivation process. Eur J Agron 71:141148 . doi: 10.1016/j.eja.2015.09.013
Leiva 2015c: Leival FJ, Blanco-Fernández J, Martínez-Camara E, et al (2015) Mushroom cultivation process, agaricus bisporus variety: comparison between traditional and climate controlled cultivation and identification of environmental impacts of the production processes. 3rd Int Work Simul Energy, Sustain Dev Environ SESDE 2015 4650
Leiva 2016: Leiva FJ, Saenz-Díez JC, Martínez E, et al (2016) Environmental impact of mushroom compost production. J Sci Food Agric 96:39833990 . doi: 10.1002/jsfa.7587
DAFM 2012: DAFM (2012) Pesticide Usage in Ireland, Mushroom crops survey, report 2011, Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine, Pesticide Control Division, downloaded on http://www.pcs.agriculture.gov.ie/media/pesticides/content/sud/pesticidestatistics/Pesticde%20Usage%20-%202011%20Mushroom%20Survey%20Report.pdf in August 2018
Potocnik 2015: Potocnik I, Stepanovic M, Rekanovic E, et al (2015) Disease control by chemical and biological fungicides in cultivated mushrooms: Button mushroom, oyster mushroom and shiitake. Pestic i fitomedicina 30:201208 . doi: 10.2298/PIF1504201P
Robinson 2018: Robinson B, Winans K, Kendall A, et al (2018) A life cycle assessment of Agaricus bisporus mushroom production in the USA. Int J Life Cycle Assess 112 . doi: 10.1007/s11367-018-1456-6

activityName: Great Scallop, Pecten maximus, BSBrieuc, Dredge, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024
Production-weighted average activity of 19 boats fishing for great scallop in the Bay of Saint Brieuc (dredge)

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant la coquille Saint-Jacques à la drague en Baie de Saint-Brieuc.
Fishery description : In France, one of the main habitats of great scallop is the Bay of Saint Brieuc (Brittany). Dredgers fishing for great scallop there are 9 to 15 meters long ships. They are disseminated all around the Bay of Saint Brieuc, in Erquy, Saint Quay Portrieux etc... They go out for a few hours trip and only fish scallops from October to March (local legislation). They use the dredge technique and only land scallops. Great scallop is landed whole and fresh (conversion ratio - muscle to whole : 7) in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : Even though no F/Fmsy data is available, the Bay of Saint Brieuc great scallop habitat is not considered overfished (Ifremer COSB 2016 data).
Pressure on stocks indicator : 0,00E+00 (100% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).
Refers to : Average annual activity of boats fishing for great scallop in the Bay of Saint-Brieuc (dredge).

activityName: Apricot, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
This dataset represents the global average for Apricot, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to FAOSTAT data for 2010:
 - France: 19%
 - Spain: 11%
 - Turkey: 10%
 - Italy: 9%
These countries together represent 49% of global export. 
All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Apricot.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.0 (i.e. very good quality)

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
"Translated name: Almonds, at farm (WFLDB 3.5)
Included processes: The inventory includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the orchard, i.e. fertiliser and pesticide application, mowing, harvesting, irrigation and prune in winter. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on the farm. Direct field emissions from crop production activities and from land use change are considered. The establishment phase of the orchard, i.e. tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase. No processing included (hulling and shelling). 
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of almonds. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year for the reference period of 2009 - 2012: Yield_ (2.9 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 2133 m3/ha). System boundary: an average year of the productive phase is regarded

activityName: Lamb, fresh meat, at slaughterhouse (WFLDB)
comment:
The full description of the animal production system is available in the WFLDB documentation report: Bengoa X., Chappuis C., Guignard C., Liernur A., Kounina A., Papadimitriou C., Rossi V. & Bayart J-B.  (2019) World Food LCA Database Documentation. Version 3.5, November 2019. Quantis, Lausanne, Switzerland.

The inventory includes the processes for lamb slaughtering, namely energy carriers, tap water, packaging film, chemicals, transport from the farm to the slaughterhouse and slaughterhouse infrastructure. 

The multi-output dataset generates the following co-products: fresh meat, food grade bones, food grade fat, cat. 3 slaughter by-products, hides and skins and cat. 1 and 2 materials and waste.

Economic allocation was applied according to PEFCR 6.3, based on 2019 data from the European Fat Processors and Renderers Association (http://www.efpra.eu/), representative of a large share of European markets.

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

activityName: Kraft paper {RER}| kraft paper production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Kraft paper {RER}| kraft paper production | Cut-off, S

Kraft paper is produced from chemical pulp produced in the kraft process. Kraft paper can be used for a number of flexible packaging applications such as paper sacks, wrapping papers and paper bags. Within kraft paper, Sack kraft paper is a porous kraft paper with high elasticity and high tear resistance, designed for packaging products with high demands for strength and durability. The data was collected specifically for Sack kraft paper but are representative for all kraft paper production. The dataset represents a mix of white (bleached) and brown (unbleached) paper.

Data in this model is from a study by CEPI Eurokraft in 2020.

The dataset represents average data calculated from several European Sack kraft paper mills and the production year 2018. Although the data was collected specifically for sack kraft paper production, discussions with the technical experts at the mills reveal that the data are applicable for other flexible kraft packaging papers

The majority of the mills in the study are integrated mills, but some "semi-integrated mills" were included, Semi-integrated mills are either an integrated mill that has been split into two companies (pulp production and paper production) where the pulp producer has not participated in the study. Or a production site where one type of paper is made from virgin pulp and the other type of paper is made from market pulp.

The energy sources at an integrated pulp and paper mills consists of external and internal fuels plus electricity from the grid and internally produced electricity. External fuels can be fossil or biobased. The internal fuels mainly consist of the black liquor and bark from the wood input for pulp production. Black liquor is the by-product of chemical pulping. It contains almost all of the inorganic cooking chemicals along with the lignin and other organic matter separated from the wood during pulping in the digester. The initial concentration of weak black liquor is about 15% dry solids in water. It is concentrated to firing conditions between 65% and 85% dry solids concentration. It is then burned in the "Recovery boiler". There are two purposes of burning the black liquor, one is to recover the inorganic cooking chemicals, the other is to make use of the energy in the organic portion of the black liquor. Source: Adams. T.N (editor) et al, "Kraft recovery boilers", 1997

The following air emissions were reported in the study: CO2 (fossil and biogenic), CH4 (fossil), N2O (fossil+ biogenic), CO (fossil+ biogenic), SO2, H2S, TRS, Total S, NOx, NH3, NMVOC, particles (all sizes), Pb and Hg. The listed air emissions are the most important emissions for the kraft paper production and cover all emissions at the mill, both from the cooking and recovering processes and combustion of fuels at different points at the plant.

For a more complete air emission profile for Sack kraft paper production, however, additional air emissions (beyond the ones listed above) were added for the combustion of the external fuels and internal using LCI datasets for combustion of different fuels as proxy. The air emissions were calculated based on the mix of the external and internal fuels in the study and more information about the fuel mix and the proxy are provided under "Extrapolations". No proxy was available for the combustion of black liquor, biological fibre slush, and tall oil. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry.

Production volume: 1990144000 kg
Included activities start: The process starts with the transports of wood and pulp to paper mill.
Included activities end: The activity includes transports to paper mill, wood handling, chemical pulping, paper production, energy production on-site and internal waste water treatment.
The activity ends with the paper leaving the factory gate.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe
Technology level: Current
Technology: Average of present used technology in 2018
Start date: 01/01/2018
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Statistics from CEPI Eurokraft for Sack production in Europe 2018. Production volume valid for 2018.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Lentil {CA-SK}| lentil production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2 in the original Ecoinvent LCI :
- Replacement of the negativ emission in the original LCI by 0
- Replacement of the transormation land use flow unspecified by the annual crop non-irrigated

This dataset represents the production of 1 tonne of dried lentil product with a dry matter content of 84% at minimum  during May-August, 2019, at 84924.57 ha lentil farms located in the Province of Saskatchewan, Canada. Farms have Yield_ of 1701.66 kg dried matter per ha for this crop cycle. The system boundaries include the production of all of crop inputs (e.g. seeds, fertilizers, crop protection products, and fuel). There is an estimated 0.49 kg of N fixation per tonne of lentils produced in this region that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. Irrigation is not included since it is rarely performed for lentils in this region. Sowing date for the crop is May, 2019 and harvesting date is August, 2020. Seeding rate is 0.06 kg/tonne of lentil production. Fertilizer applied contain nitrogen (as N) 5.19 kg/tonne, phosphate (as P2O5) 18.12 kg/tonne, potash (as K2O) 1.77 kg/tonne, sulfur (as S) 2.66 kg/tonne, and zinc (as Zn) 0.05 kg/tonne. Predominant crop protection applied contain active ingredients of Glyphosate 642.36 g/tonne, Ethalfluralin 76.88 g/tonne, and Sethoxydim 34.00 g/tonne. Machinery is used for tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, and burndown/desiccant application with total fuel consumption of 51.60 kg/tonne.

None

Production volume: 144758.796875 kg
Included activities start: Starting inputs for this activity include seed, fertilizer, crop protection products and fuel on the farm. This activity begins with soil preparation about 37 weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in 1st week of May and sowing of seeds started about 5 days after soil preparation.
Included activities end: This activity ends with lentil drying to <16% moisture at farm gate. Carbon and nitrogen emissions associated with above- and below-ground biomass are accounted for using the DNDC model. This model was also used to calculate a nitrogen fixation credit that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. For lentils in this region, the N credit was estimated to be 0.49 kg/t.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Saskatchewan
Technology level: Current
Technology: Production of lentil includes farm practices from tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, burndown/desiccant application, to drying.
Start date: 01/01/2017
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: April - May 2019; Harvesting date main crop: August, 2017-2019. The soil cultivation, sowing and harvesting dates are the data collected by the farmers. Total time from date of sowing to date of harvesting comes to 119 days. The data is collected for three crop cycles. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoinvent.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Bell pepper {GLO}| bell pepper production, in heated greenhouse | Cut-off, U
This dataset has been copied and adapted from Ecoinvent for Agribalyse : 
- energy for heating greenhouse has been set to 0 to represent production in unheated greenhouse for French market.
- inputs have been regionalized for France / Europe when possible
_____________________________________________________________________________

This dataset represents green bell pepper production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 80 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 6 months.

Greenhouse production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:

 - bell pepper production, GLO, 2010 - 2010 (660610cf-3ee8-4c35-a3ce-4403d14d69c8)]

Production volume: 34497462272 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.5 month and it's use of electricity. It also includes the electricity use in the greenhouse. And an average amount of heating energy for the production and the seedling production is included. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). 
Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

activityName: Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 8.000e+9 kg

IN: PV = 6.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.75

US: PV = 2.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.25

Yield of the global dataset = 28125 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the IN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg mint. The average Yield_ from 1999 is 16.5 t/ha. The data are representative for mint production in India, Uttar Pradesh, used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 160-50-50 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.74 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing mint produced in India for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 8000000000 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing seedlings, i.e. seedlings from roots.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the clearing of the field (removing of mint plants). The dataset includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the field including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (4 years), and the clearing of the field. 
The establishment phase of the field includes seedlings nursery, soil cultivation, planting, herbicide use and irrigation.
The productive phase of the field includes machine operations, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting, transport on farm and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the field is cleared by removing the mint plants.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include drying.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology:

End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period:

activityName: Carrot, conventional, national average, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

activityName: Peanut {IN}| peanut production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Peanut {IN}| peanut production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of peanuts. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 1 t/ha. The data are representative for peanut production in India used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-60-0 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.81 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peanuts produced in India amounts to 30% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peanuts produced in India for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 6338124800 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of peanuts at farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for India
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period:

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for 'fava bean, in the Global geography.

The dataset considers transportation from the producer to the consumer of this product, transportation distances are based on default transport distances for markets (found in file 'Default Transport Assumptions' at https://www.ecoinvent.org/support/documents-and-files/documents-and-files.html).

Included activities end: This activity ends with the supply of  'fava bean', to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.

activityName: Polyethylene, high density, granulate {RER}| production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Polyethylene, high density, granulate {RER}| polyethylene production, high density, granulate | Cut-off, S

The dataset represents the production mix of commercial HDPE production technologies: slurry suspension polymerisation, gas phase polymerisation and solution polymerisation using Ziegler-Natta, Philips, and Metallocene catalysts.

HDPE is mainly produced with the slurry suspension, solution or the gas phase process, which belong to the low-pressure technologies. As catalysts, usually Ziegler-Natta or Phillips-type catalysts are applied, but metallocene-type catalysts can also be used. Due to this wide range of choice of process technology, reactor type, or catalyst type, a typical process for HDPE production cannot be defined.

The suspension polymerisation can be described as precipitation process. The formation of the polymer takes place in a hydrocarbon diluent and under conditions, where the monomer is soluble in the solution. The precipitated polymer, however, is insoluble and forms a fine suspension. The polymer is then separated by centrifugation. The suspension process can be combined with a stirred tank reactor or a loop reactor. Different diluents can be chosen, like C5 to C9 hydrocarbons, hexane, or isobutane.

For solution polymerisation, the hydrocarbon solvent (C9-C6) is kept at high temperature (>130 °C) to ensure that the formed polymer stays dissolved after production. In a subsequent step, the solvent is evaporated and recycled, and the liquid polymer can directly be sent to the extruder. 

In the gas phase processes a fluidised bed of polymer particles and catalyst is maintained by a steady gaseous monomer feed from the bottom of the reactor. Polymer powder is continuously extracted at the bottom of the fluidised bed reactor. Unreacted monomer gas from the top is compressed and recycled to the reactor inlet. Catalyst, and co-catalyst if necessary, is also continuously fed to the reactor. Typically Ziegler-Natta catalysts are used for gas phase polymerisation where the catalyst is supported on inert silica particles so that the reaction takes place at the catalyst surface.

After the reaction phase, most of the residual (unreacted) monomers (which are mostly present as gases) are separated from the polymer and are either recycled back into the process or flared of. Depending on the purity of the separated monomers, the gas can either be fed directly back into the production line or the monomers are returned to a purification unit. To limit the accumulation of impurities in the process, usually a small side-stream (purge) of the unreacted gas is sent back to the cracker or to a dedicated purification unit. After polymerisation, the polymer is usually fed di-rectly into a hot melt extruder, where additives can be added to the melted polymer if required. The polymer is then pelletised in an underwater pelletiser. The pelletised product is dried, blended where required and degassed.

Production volume: 6499999744 kg
Included activities start: Acitivity starts with monomers and comonomers entering the polymerisation plant. Energy supply is included in terms of heat production inside the battery limits of the plant. Steam and electricity supply is outside the activity.
Included activities end: Activity ends with polymer granulate leaving the factory.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe

Technology: Coverage of production capacity in Europe: 68%

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Peach {ES}| peach production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of peach. The average Yield_ from 2009-2012 is 27 t/ha. The data are representative for peach production in Spain used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 14-55-90 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 12.71 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peaches produced in Spain amounts to 34% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peaches produced in Spain for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.8 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 1257250944 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (19 years, 1500 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Spain
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of fava beans (fresh matter). The Yield_ is 3782 kg/ha at a moisture content at storage of 13%.

None

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Production volume: 4 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop. The inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers and pesticides are considered. Farm manure as an organic fertiliser is only accounted for in terms of direct field emissions; all pre-processes are included in the animal production systems.
Included activities end: The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvest, transport from field to regional processing centre (10 km) and drying of grains. Further, direct field emissions are included. The cultivation of green manure during winter before sowing beans is also included. This activity ends after drying of grains at the regional processing centre.

activityName: Peanut {AR}| peanut production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Peanut {AR}| peanut production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of peanuts. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 2.57 t/ha. The data are representative for peanut production in Argentina from the central region of Córdoba at the University of Rio Cuarto. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 0-0-0 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 2.56 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peanuts produced in Argentina amounts to 18% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peanuts produced in Argentina for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.0 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 650947008 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of peanuts at farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Argentina
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Fennel {GLO}| fennel production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents fennel production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 16 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 2.75 months.

Field production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 2.40114694E11 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.75 month and it's use of electricity.  And the greenhouse heating energy for the seedling production.The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Current
Technology: Integrated Production
Start date: 01/01/2010
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Mandarin, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Translated name: Mandarin, at farm (WFLDB 3.5)
Included processes: The inventory includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the orchard, i.e. fertiliser and pesticide application, mulching, mowing, harvesting and irrigation. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on the farm. Direct field emissions from crop production activities and from land use change are considered. The establishment phase of the orchard, i.e. tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of mandarins. The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year for the reference period of 2009 - 2012: yield (8.1 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 3303 m3/ha). System boundary: an average year of the productive phase is regarded; included are also the per year of lifetime calculated emissions for nursery, materials for planting, establishment and clearing phase; at farm without storage. Number of years from planting to clearing (lifetime): 30 years   - Waste treatment after clearing of the orchard: Wooden posts and tree wood go to incineration, concrete posts go to land fill, iron wires go to recycling. The data are representative for mandarin production in China used for the export market.
Comment: Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.8 (i.e. good quality)

Technology: Conventional production
Version: 2.2
Energy values: Undefined
Local category: Landwirtschaftliche Produktion
Local subcategory: Pflanzenbau

activityName: Transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 7.5-16 ton, EURO5, R134a refrigerant, cooling {GLO}| transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 7.5-16 ton, EURO5, R134a refrigerant, cooling | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 7.5-16 ton, EURO5, R134a refrigerant, cooling {GLO}| transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 7.5-16 ton, EURO5, R134a refrigerant, cooling | Cut-off, S

https://db3.ecoinvent.org/images/4482b28c-ed41-487d-b331-d306ca598890 [Image URL, right click copy paste to a browser to view]

This dataset represents transport of goods in lorry with atmosphere controlled (temperature, humidity, etc.) storage space set up for cooling.

While the majority of the atmosphere controlled (cold chain, refrigerated transport) road transportation is conducted with truck with semi-trailer in the cities this goods is often transported by smaller rigid trucks with refrigeration machine.

Production volume: 7853151232 tkm
Included activities start: This activity starts with input of fuel, road and vehicle infrastructure including refrigeration machine. It includes also exhaust and non-exhaust emissions.
Included activities end: This datasets combines the transport of 1 ton of goods over 1km by a lorry with refrigeration machine. The goods themselves are not included.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Modern
Technology: https://db3.ecoinvent.org/images/1a5c3ed8-2d10-4eae-9d60-d43536cce3ff [Image URL, right click copy paste to a browser to view]

The construction of the refrigeration machine does not change very much in time. What might be changing is the 1) type of refrigerant, 2) energy consumption - efficiency and 3) leakage of the refrigerant. 

The datasets on transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine present in the ecoinvent database represent several scenarios with different type of refrigerant, energy consumption and leakage of the refrigerant.. 

The technology level is set reflecting the EURO classification, i.e. EURO3 is the oldest technology and EURO6 the newest. The R134a refrigerant is currently most widely used refrigerant, while the carbon dioxide, liquid is the newer more environmentally friendly solution. Therefore all the lorries using the carbon dioxide, liquid as refrigerant have higher level of technology than those using the R134a as refrigerant.

activityName: Potato, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of potato. The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year, from 2004 - 2017 (44 t/ha) produced under irrigated conditions (1183 m3/ha total water use).

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes the processes of seeds production and planting, soil preparation, fertiliser and pesticide application, irrigation and harvest. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for sprinkler irrigation. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are included.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2, Good quality

Geography: The Netherlands

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2004- 2017

Data sources:
- Yield: FAOstats average over the years 2012-2016
- Fertilisation: Bystricky, M., Nemecek, T., Alig, M., & Gaillard, G. (2014). "Challenges of comparing food and feed products from different countries of origin". Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Life Cycle Assessment in the Agri-Food Sector 8-10 October 2014 - San Francisco, (October).
- Pesticide: Total amount pesticides in potato production in Belgium is used as proxy 
Direction de l'Etat Environnomental, Département de l'étude du milieu naturel et agricole (2017). "Rapport sur l'état de l'environement Wallon 2017", SPW Editions. Retrieved in October 2018 from: http://etat.environnement.wallonie.be/files/Publications/REEW2016/DGRNE-16-16716-REEW%202016-sl-051217-prod2%20-%20basse%20résolution.pdf 
The proportion of different pesticide is derived, as proxy, from a UK survey 
Garthwaite, D.G., Thomas, M.R., Anderson, H. and Stoddart, H. (2004). "Pesticide usage survey report 202 - Arable crops in Great Britain", Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affaires and Scottish Executive Environment & Rural Affaires Department. Retrived in October 2018 from https://secure.fera.defra.gov.uk/pusstats/surveys/documents/arable2004.pdf

activityName: Dairy desserts - cat A, 500g | Packaging System, N0, All, Cardboard pots pack {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

N0, all Identification key for packaging system containing one or more element.
"Cat A", "Cat B, "Cat C", "Cat D", "Cat E", "Cat F", "Cat G","Cat H" : Categories specific to the types of packaging defined in the PACK_AGB report (e.g case of packaging for cheese).
For more information, please refer to the methodological report  : Colombin, M., Audoye, P., Farrant, L., Allain, D., Anneraud, C., Bosque, F., Besnier, A., Bozec, A.(2024). Rapport méthodologique : volet emballages Agribalyse 3.2.

The inventory refers to a pack of 4 cardboard pots and the associated elements allowing to condition a total weight of 500 g of dairy desserts.  
This inventory of packaging solution can only be used for products in sub-category "Dairy products and desserts" (PACK_AGB) : refer to the report for more details. 

The packaging solution describes the 4 cardboard/ LDPE complex pots with their complex lids and the grouping cardboard sheath. 
The data was produced from study of packaging on the French market (supermarket reference) and data collection from manufacturers.
The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. ***Application of CCF, rate of virgin and recycled materials corresponding to the FR scenario (2022) 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

The packaging solutions developed as part of the PACK_AGB project have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html 

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1
Time period: the data describing the packaging solution was collected over the period 2020-2022. 
The inventory is modelled for France. Packaging waste management is representative of packaging waste management in France. 
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".  
Property data : ADEME

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 57559834624 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.3 month and it's use of electricity. It also includes the electricity use in the greenhouse. And an average amount of heating energy for the production and the seedling production is included. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included.  
The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Current
Technology: Integrated production

activityName: Soft wheat grain, conventional, national average, animal feed, at farm gate, production {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as seed, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory is 'harvest to harvest'. Fertilizers (K, P and organic N) have been adjusted in order to account for the whole rotation.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest as 'drying', 'sorting' or 'storing', even if they happen on farm.
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of fresh matter of soft wheat (15% moisture), conventional production. 
Raw datas comes from:The data is based on literature and statistical data as well as expert judgements. 
Transformation has been performed (weightening and assignments of the flows as well as calculation of direct field emissions).
PEF  Overall data quality : 
Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2 : Good
Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2 : Good
Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 3 : Fair
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 2 : Good
Final note = 2,25 : Good data quality level
Yield: 7100.0 kg

activityName: Polyvinylchloride, suspension polymerised {RER}| polyvinylchloride production, suspension polymerisation | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Polyvinylchloride, suspension polymerised {RER}| polyvinylchloride production, suspension polymerisation | Cut-off, S

The dataset represents the production mix of commercial S-PVC production technologies

Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) is manufactured by polymerisation of vinyl chloride monomer (VCM). Polymerisation of PVC is an exothermic reaction. The pressure in the reactor is usually in the range of 0.4 - 1.2 MPa and the reaction temperature is between 35 - 70°C. During the polymerisation reaction 85 - 97% of the VCM is converted into PVC. Residual VCM is removed by stripping the polymer suspension or latex. The unreacted monomer is recovered, liquefied, and returned to polymerisation

For the polymerisation process certain process chemicals are required. Surfactants, emulsifiers and protective colloids are used to prepare and stabilize the dispersion of monomer and PVC in process water (typically around 1 kg/t VCM in suspension and around 10-20 kg/t in emulsion). Organic peroxides or peresters are used as initiators (typically 1 kg/t VCM) for the production of suspension and microsuspension PVC, while e.g. hindered phenols are used to stop the reaction (typically < 1 kg/t VCM). For the production of emulsion PVC inorganic peroxides are common.

PVC resin resulting from the suspension process (S-PVC) has a mean particle size of 50 - 200 µm. The essential differences between S-PVC grades result from the average length of polymer chains and from the porosity of the particles. Suspension PVC is always produced batch wise in a stirred vessel. The monomer is dispersed in demineralised water by the combination of mechanical stirring and surfactants. The polymerisation takes place inside the VCM droplets under the influence of VCM soluble initiators such as peresters, percarbonates, or peroxides.

Production volume: 3400000000 kg
Included activities start: Acitivity starts with monomers entering the polymerisation plant. Energy supply is included in terms of heat production inside the battery limits of the plant. Steam and electricity supply is outside the activity.
Included activities end: Activity ends with polymer granulate leaving the factory.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe
Technology level: Current
Technology: Coverage of production capacity in Europe: 88%
Start date: 01/01/2013
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Data was collected for the year 2013, processed in 2014 and published in 2015
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Lamb, fresh meat, at slaughterhouse (WFLDB)
comment:
The full description of the animal production system is available in the WFLDB documentation report: Bengoa X., Chappuis C., Guignard C., Liernur A., Kounina A., Papadimitriou C., Rossi V. & Bayart J-B.  (2019) World Food LCA Database Documentation. Version 3.5, November 2019. Quantis, Lausanne, Switzerland.

The inventory includes the processes for lamb slaughtering, namely energy carriers, tap water, packaging film, chemicals, transport from the farm to the slaughterhouse and slaughterhouse infrastructure. 

The multi-output dataset generates the following co-products: fresh meat, food grade bones, food grade fat, cat. 3 slaughter by-products, hides and skins and cat. 1 and 2 materials and waste.

Economic allocation was applied according to PEFCR 6.3, based on 2019 data from the European Fat Processors and Renderers Association (http://www.efpra.eu/), representative of a large share of European markets.

Funtional unit: 1kg of fresh lamb meat at slaughterhouse

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.3 (i.e. good quality)

Data sources:
- Zampori, L. and Pant, R., Suggestions for updating the Product Environmental Footprint (PEF) method, EUR 29682 EN, Publications Office of the European Union, Luxembourg, 2019, ISBN 978-92-76-00653-4, doi:10.2760/265244, JRC115959.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of olives. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 5 t/ha. The data are representative for olive production in Spain (Andalusia) used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-60-60 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 2.15 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The share of olives produced in Spain amounts to 37% of the global production (tonnage produced in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing olives produced in Spain for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.5 (i.e. excellent quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 6459754496 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (40 years, 250 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.

'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'maize starch', in the Global geography.

In this market, expert judgement was used to develop product specific transport distance estimations.

The product 'maize starch' is from milled maize grain. Maize grain is an annual crop.

activityName: Packaging glass, white {RER w/o CH+DE}| production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Packaging glass, white {RER w/o CH+DE}| packaging glass production, white | Cut-off, S

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of white packaging glass from a mix of primary and secondary raw materials.

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

CO2 emissions have been recalculated from the carbon content in raw materials and fuels.

Material inputs are estimation based on literature sources and a Swiss production site. Energy and water consumption, emissions, and waste production are estimation based on literature sources. Infrastructure is an estimation based on average European packaging glass factories.

Production volume: 12807795712 kg
Included activities start: From the reception of precursors silica sand, soda, unsorted glass cullets, limestone, dolomite, feldspar, and chemicals  inorganics at the factory gate.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the production of 1 kg of white packaging glass. The dataset includes material and energy inputs, water consumption, emissions to air and water, waste production, transport and infrastructure.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe without Germany and Switzerland
Technology level: Old
Technology: Packaging glass is produced in a two stage moulding process with pressing and blowing techniques. The whole process is fully automatic and consists of five different stages:

None

1.	Production of a molten glass piece (gob) with correct weight and temperature. 

None

None

2.	Forming of the primary shape in a first mould (blank mould) with compressed air pressure

None

3.	Transfer to the final mould (finish mould)

None

4.	Bringing the shaping process to an end by blowing the container with compressed air until the shape of the final mould

None

5.	Post forming processes

The melting process is the central one. As the first glass forming material, sand, has a very high melting point. Soda as a fluxing agent is used to reduce the melting temperature. When heating soda, this is decomposed into sodium oxide Na2O, the actual fluxing agent, and into carbon dioxide that is released. Metal oxides in form of limestone (CaCO3 that decomposes to CaO), dolomite (-> Ca- and Mg-Oxides), feldspar are used as stabilizators and therefore to improve the hardness and chemical resistance of glass. activityName: Polyethylene terephthalate, granulate, bottle grade {RER}| production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Polyethylene terephthalate, granulate, bottle grade {RER}| polyethylene terephthalate production, granulate, bottle grade | Cut-off, S

The dataset represents the production mix of commercial bottle grade PET production technologies. PET production covered by this study is by esterification of ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid (PTA). The esterification process is carried out under moderate pressure (2.5-5.5 bar) and at high temperature (230-270 °C) whilst the water formed during the reaction is continuously removed via distillation. 

The monomers of PET production, purified terephthalic acid (PTA) and mono ethylene glycol (MEG) are polymerised in the liquid phase to produce amorphous PET. This form of the polymer is suitable for the production of fibres and film. Most bottle grade PET today is a copolyester slightly modified through addition of 1-2% Benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (isophthalic acid, IPA) or 4(hydroxymethyl)cyclohexyl-methanol (cyclohexanedimethanol, CHDM) during polymerisation.

The first step of PET production is the esterification of PTA and MEG to bishydroxyethyl terepthalate (BHET) with water as a by-product at around 220-260 °C in the presence of an anti-mony catalyst (usually Sb2O3). Water forming from the esterification reaction is continuously removed by distillation. Formation of the undesired side product diethylene glycol is suppressed by maintaining low molar ratios of MEG:PTA (less than 2 or even 1.5). BHET is then sent to Pre-polycondensation in a second reactor under a vacuum and further to a melt polycondensation reactor at higher temperatures and still under vacuum. Vacuum is required to remove water and other side products and to drive the reaction equilibrium towards the polymer.

As melt polymerisation does not produce high molecular weight, a subsequent polymerisation step, solid state polymerisation (SSP) is required for bottle grade PET. During SSP the polymer chain lengths are increased by heat in the absence of oxygen and water, by means of either vacuum or purging with an inert gas to drive off the by-products of reactions. The reaction is driven by temperature, pressure, and the diffusion of by-products from the interior of the pellet to the surface. The product of SSP is a partially crystalline resin that can be used to produce bottles via injection moulding and stretch blow moulding.

Production volume: 3400000000 kg
Included activities start: Acitivity starts with PTA entering the polymerisation plant. Both amorphous and bottle grade PET produciton are included. Energy supply is included in terms of heat production inside the battery limits of the plant. Steam and electricity supply is outside the activity.
Included activities end: Activity ends with polymer granulate leaving the factory.

Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvest, transport from field to regional processing centre (10 km) and drying of grains. This activity ends after drying of grains at the regional processing centre.

activityName: Lentil {CA-SK}| lentil production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2 in the original Ecoinvent LCI :
- Replacement of the negativ emission in the original LCI by 0
- Replacement of the transormation land use flow unspecified by the annual crop non-irrigated

This dataset represents the production of 1 tonne of dried lentil product with a dry matter content of 84% at minimum  during May-August, 2019, at 84924.57 ha lentil farms located in the Province of Saskatchewan, Canada. Farms have Yield_ of 1701.66 kg dried matter per ha for this crop cycle. The system boundaries include the production of all of crop inputs (e.g. seeds, fertilizers, crop protection products, and fuel). There is an estimated 0.49 kg of N fixation per tonne of lentils produced in this region that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. Irrigation is not included since it is rarely performed for lentils in this region. Sowing date for the crop is May, 2019 and harvesting date is August, 2020. Seeding rate is 0.06 kg/tonne of lentil production. Fertilizer applied contain nitrogen (as N) 5.19 kg/tonne, phosphate (as P2O5) 18.12 kg/tonne, potash (as K2O) 1.77 kg/tonne, sulfur (as S) 2.66 kg/tonne, and zinc (as Zn) 0.05 kg/tonne. Predominant crop protection applied contain active ingredients of Glyphosate 642.36 g/tonne, Ethalfluralin 76.88 g/tonne, and Sethoxydim 34.00 g/tonne. Machinery is used for tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, and burndown/desiccant application with total fuel consumption of 51.60 kg/tonne.

None

Production volume: 144758.796875 kg
Included activities start: Starting inputs for this activity include seed, fertilizer, crop protection products and fuel on the farm. This activity begins with soil preparation about 37 weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in 1st week of May and sowing of seeds started about 5 days after soil preparation.
Included activities end: This activity ends with lentil drying to <16% moisture at farm gate. Carbon and nitrogen emissions associated with above- and below-ground biomass are accounted for using the DNDC model. This model was also used to calculate a nitrogen fixation credit that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. For lentils in this region, the N credit was estimated to be 0.49 kg/t.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Saskatchewan
Technology level: Current
Technology: Production of lentil includes farm practices from tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, burndown/desiccant application, to drying.
Start date: 01/01/2017
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: April - May 2019; Harvesting date main crop: August, 2017-2019. The soil cultivation, sowing and harvesting dates are the data collected by the farmers. Total time from date of sowing to date of harvesting comes to 119 days. The data is collected for three crop cycles. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoinvent.

Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 8.000e+9 kg

IN: PV = 6.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.75

US: PV = 2.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.25

Yield of the global dataset = 28125 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the IN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg mint. The average Yield_ from 1999 is 16.5 t/ha. The data are representative for mint production in India, Uttar Pradesh, used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 160-50-50 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.74 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing mint produced in India for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 8000000000 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing seedlings, i.e. seedlings from roots.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the clearing of the field (removing of mint plants). The dataset includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the field including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (4 years), and the clearing of the field. 
The establishment phase of the field includes seedlings nursery, soil cultivation, planting, herbicide use and irrigation.
The productive phase of the field includes machine operations, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting, transport on farm and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the field is cleared by removing the mint plants.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include drying.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology:

End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of peanuts. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 3.5 t/ha. The data are representative for peanut production in China used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 80-27-28 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 11.25 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peanuts produced in China amounts to 10% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peanuts produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 17201534976 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of peanuts at farm gate. The dataset includes total diesel combusted in agricultural machinery, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. 
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.
