activityName: Palm fruit bunch, with deforestation, on land recently transformed, animal feed, at farm gate {MY} U
comment:
[This dataset was already contained in the AGRIBALYSE 1.3 database. It was not individually updated during the transfer to AGRIBALYSE 2.0. Therefore, the method and models used can differ from other AGRIBALYSE 2.0 productions. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the AGRIBALYSE 1.3 quality guidelines. It may have been subject to central changes described in the AGRIBALYSE change report.]

 - supporting LCI (based on the project ECOALIM).
Production of palm fruit bunch, associated with deforestation, in Malaysia. Data from Ecoinvent.
Category: Agricultural production, plant production
Product Name: Fruit de palmier a huile
Type of data: LCI, crop management sequence
Data status: restrictive
Location: MY (Malaysia)
Documentation from ecoinvent :
_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
The inventory for the cultivation of oil palms GLO on recently transformed land  is modelled on the basis of data from Malaysia. Machine usage is modelled with Malaysian processings and Swiss diesel consumptions. The average annual clear-cutting of primary forest associated with the cultivation of oil palms is calculated as land tenure, arable land (the replacement of plantations is considered without any effect).  The loss/gain in carbon from mineral soils/organic soils/biomass growth is calculated as "carbon, organic, from soil or biomass stock" and released as "carbon dioxide, from soil or biomass stock". Transports are calculated with standard distances. The functional unit is 1 kg palm fruit bunches (fresh mass with a water content of 47 %). Carbon content: 0.313 kg/kg fresh mass. Biomass energy content: 16 MJ/kg fresh mass. Yield: 24978 kg/ha. The emissions of N2O and NH3 to air are calculated with standard emission factors for mineral fertilizers from Nemecek et al. 2004. The emission of nitrate to water is calculated with an estimated nitrogen loss factor of 20%.
[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]
Production volume: 90935000000 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts after the provision of land tenure, arable land, which is provided by the clear-cutting of rainforest. This activity assumes palm fruit bunch production on a plantation with a lifetime of 20 years and represents the average operation expenditures of the production of 1 kg of fresh fruit bunch averaged across the whole lifetime including establishment, operation and clearing of the plantation. The inputs of mineral fertilisers, pesticides and irrigation water are considered. The input of seed is considered neglectable compared to the plantation lifetime of 20 years. It is assumed that no organic fertilisers are applied.
Included activities end: The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Most operations are done by hand. Machine operations are: fertilisation, irrigation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, transport of harvested fruit bunches from field to farm (25 km) and clearing of the plantation (wood chopping). Further, direct field emissions are included. This activity ends after harvest and transport to the farm at the farm gate.
Energy values: Net Values (default)
Geography: The inventory refers to Malaysia
Technology level: 3 Current (default)
Technology: Cultivation of oil palms.
Start date: 2002-01-01
End date: 2014-12-31
Is data valid for entire period: true
Time period: Time of publications
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

 This process describes the average consumption mix of European pilchard or sardine in France.

For all fish data are based on expert say.

activityName: Banana {RoW}| banana production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Banana {RoW}| banana production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 3.933e+10 kg

IN: PV = 2.780e+10 kg; weight = 0.7069

EC: PV = 7.502e+9 kg; weight = 0.1908

CR: PV = 2.019e+9 kg; weight = 0.05134

CO: PV = 2.005e+9 kg; weight = 0.05098

Yield of the global dataset = 36502.128103 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the IN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of banana, at standard water content (78.1%). The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2009 - 2012: Yield_ (35.1 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 13705 m3/ha). The data are representative for banana production in India used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 57-0-146 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 1.84 m3/ha of liquid manure and 2.48 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 4.2 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of bananas produced in India amounts to 0.4% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing banana produced in India for the export market. 

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.5 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 62785376256 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (20 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
 The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology:

End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Lemon {ES}| lemon production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of lemons. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 37 t/ha. The data are representative for lemons production in Spain used for the export market. §

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of lemons produced in Spain amounts to 16% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing lemons produced in Spain for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.3 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 674371008 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (30 years, 256 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers (mineral and organic) and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.

activityName: Soybean, not associated to deforestation {BR}| market for soybean, without transport | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
To use this inventory, any soy must not have been produced on land that was deforested the last 20 years i.e. on the time period 2004-2024.
The 20 years threshold is based on the amount of time needed for stored carbon to reach equilibrium (often 20 years in the IPCC default methods).


Adaptation made for Agribalyse :
Mix is adapted to represent brasilians regions not associated with deforestation : these 3 regions do not contain any transformation flows linked to the transformation from Primary forest to arable land. 
Production shares are derived from provenances of soybean produced in Brazil and imported provided by ecoinvent data "Soybean {BR}| market for BR, without transport | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent" . To build this deforestation-free mix for France, the brazilian states with primary forest to arable land transformation flows were discarded and the production shares of the 3 states retained for this deforestation-free mix were normalized to 100%.
____________________________


This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'soybean', in the geography of Brazil.

This is dataset represents the transport of 1 kg of soybeans from the production farm to the plant producting soybean meal and soybean oil. No losses are considered in this dataset.

The product 'soybean' is a seed. It is an annual crop. The ecoinvent database also contains this product from organic and Swiss integrated production.

Production volume: 115711918080 kg
Included activities start: The activity starts at the gate of soybean cultivation farm.
Included activities end: The activity ends with the provision of soybean grains to the soybean meal and oil production plant.

Geography: The inventory is modelled for Brazil
Technology level: Current
Technology: The data are intended to reflect current equipment and processes on a Brazilian level.

activityName: Lettuce {GLO}| lettuce production, in heated greenhouse | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents lettuce production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 50 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 3.4 months.

Greenhouse production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 2.3622366E10 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.3 month and it's use of electricity. It also includes the electricity use in the greenhouse. And an average amount of heating energy for the production and the seedling production is included. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Current
Technology: Integrated Production

End date: 31/12/2024

activityName: Mandarin {ES}| mandarin production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Mandarin {ES}| mandarin production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of mandarins. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 30 t/ha. The data are representative for mandarin production in Spain used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 200-80-270 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 13.86 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of mandarins produced in Spain amounts to 33% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing mandarins produced in Spain for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 3.0 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 2046639488 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (30 years, 256 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers (mineral and organic) and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Spain
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Sweet sorghum grain {RoW}| sweet sorghum production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the cultivation of sweet sorghum on an area of 1 ha producing the co-products sweet sorghum grain and sweet sorghum stem. The Yield_ of sweet sorghum grain is 3860 kg/ha at a moisture content at storage of 9.1%, the Yield_ of sweet sorghum stem is 48263 kg/ha at a moisture content of 73%.

None

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Production volume: 56983326720 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop. The inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers and pesticides are considered. It is assumed that no organic fertilisers are applied. Seed input is approximated by reducing the Yield_ by 5 kg (required amount of seed per hectare for sowing)
Included activities end: The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvest and transport from field to farm (15 km). Further, direct field emissions are included. This activity ends after harvest at the farm gate.

activityName: Saithe, Pollachius virens, NorthSea, Bottom Trawl, average, fresh, at landing {EU} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 4 boats fishing for fresh saithe in the North Sea (bottom trawl).

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant le lieu noir frais au chalut de fond en mer du Nord.
Fishery description : in France, fresh saithe is fished in the North Sea by 45 meters long ships. They are based in Boulogne-sur-Mer but can be brought to land in Lochinver (GB) and Hanstlhom (DK) too. They go out for 10 days fishing trips and spend between 250 and 280 days at sea per year. Their fishing area corresponds to the entire North Sea. They use the bottom trawl technique and land other benthic species such as ling or hake. Saithe is landed gutted and fresh (conversion ratio : 1,19).
Stock status : The North Sea saithe stock is not considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 0,78 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 3,51E-08 (95,5% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant la sardine à la bolinche dans le Golfe de Gascogne.
Fishery description : In France, sardine is fished in the Bay of Biscay by 15 to 20 meters long ships. They are mainly based in Saint-Guénolé, Concarneau and Douarnenez but a few units are present around Bayonne. They go out at night for 8 to 10 hours fishing trips and spend between 150 and 200 days at sea per year. Their fishing area is off the French Atlantic coasts. They use the seine technique and land other pelagic species such as mackerel, anchovy and horse-mackerel. Sardines are landed whole and fresh in the ships' french home ports.

comment:
This dataset represents 1 kg of palm date fruit conditioned and dried in Tunisia. All the exchanges are calculated per kg of palm date and are based on field data from the main industrial palm date exporter in Tunisia. The inventory includes the following activities: sorting, washing, fumigating, cooling, heating, drying and glucosing. The packaging has not been taking into account.Regarding waste management, palm date kernel are recovered as animal feed. The annual productivity of the plant is 13000 tons of palm dates Deglet Noor (97% of the plam dates are conventionals). The cultivar of the dates studies is Deglet Noor. Tunisia is the world's largest exporter of Deglet Noor. 

Production volume: 5574121.0 kg
Included activities start: The activity starts when palm date fruit arrives to the plant in order to be conditioned. 
Included activities end: The activity ends when the fruit has undergone all processing steps. The palm date is then ready to  be packed and send to the importing country. The facility, the infrastructures and the machineries has not been taking into account.

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 28512262144 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 4.5 months and it's use of electricity.  
And the greenhouse heating energy for the seedling production. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

activityName: Wheat grain, at farm {GLO} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
This dataset represents the global average for wheat grain, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to FAOSTAT data for 2016:
 - Russia: 14%
 - USA: 13%
 - Canada: 11%
 - France: 10%
 - Australia: 9%
These countries together represent 57% of global export. 
Non-irrigated wheat is assumed for all exporting countries. 

All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of wheat grain with a water content of 15%.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality)

_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Hazelnuts in shell at the farm. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per hectare and year: 1.45574 t/ha, obtained under irrigated conditions (total  amount of water 1541.0 m3/ha). 

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, and seeds, as well as field work processes and the associated diesel combusted in agricultural machinery. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for sprinkler irrigation. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are included.

Data quality rating(DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality)

Geography: Italy

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2002 - 2017

Data sources: 
- Yield: FAOstats average over the years 2013 - 2017
- Tree density, orchard lifetime and mineral fertilizers: Agrion, Fondazione per la ricerca l'innovazione e lo sviluppo tecnologico dell'agricoltura piemontese. Il nocciolo in Piemonte, Linee techniche 2016. Consulted in August 2019 on https://www.nocciolare.it/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Linee-guida-2016-Agrion.pdf
- Irrigation: Bignami, C., Cristofori, V. Scossa, A., Bertazza, G. (2002). Effetto dell'irrigazione sulla composizione della nocciola. 2e Convegno Nazionale sul Nocciolo, pp.206 - 212.

Biological Forum - An International Journal, pp.807 - 813., and from the Unites States: Julian, J.W., Seavert, C.F., Olsen, J.L., (2008). Orchard Economics: The costs and returns of establishing and producing hazelnuts in the Willamette Valley. Oregon State University, Extension Service. Consulted in August 2019 on http://arec.oregonstate.edu/oaeb/files/pdf/EM8748-E.pdf
- Husk residue management (biowaste): Gürdil GAK, Özcan Baz Y, Demirel B, Demirel C (2016) Pelleting hazelnut husk residues for biofuel. 6th International Conference on Trends in Agricultural Engineering.

activityName: Common Sole, Solea solea, BBiscay, Trammel Net, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 11 boats fishing for sole in the Bay of Biscay (trammel net)

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant la sole au filet trémail dans le Golfe de Gascogne.
Fishery description : In France, gillneters fishing for sole in the Bay of Biscay are 12 to 20 meters long ships. They are disseminated all along the French Atlantic coast, from Le Guilvinec to Bayonne. They go out for a 10 hours trip and spend approximately 200 days at sea per year. Their fishing area is off the Bay of Biscay coasts. They use the trammel net technique and fish other species such as anglerfishes. Sole is generally landed gutted and fresh (conversion ratio : 1,04) in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : The Bay of Biscay sole stock is considered slightly overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,09 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 4,23E-06 (60,0% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).
Refers to : Average annual activity of boats fishing for sole in the Bay of Biscay (trammel net)

activityName: Spinach {CH}| spinach production, conventional, plain region | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of spinach calculated on a sectoral average of the production of 1 ha with a yield of 16727 kg at a moisture content of 92.0%. The yield is based on average yield from 2017-2021 in Agristat corrected by region and production system differences in AGRIDEA (2021). Modelled crop duration is 1.8 months, preceeded by 8.2 months of non-hibernating green manure crop. The data are representative for conventional spinach production under tillage in the Swiss plain region. Mineral fertiliser input is 190 kg N, 35 kg P2O5, 279 kg K2O, 2.7 kg Mg. No farm manure has been applied. No organic market fertiliser has been applied.  This dataset was modelled under the aim of a sectoral view on the Swiss Agriculture. The active ingredients applied for plant protection resemble a weighted average mix per crop and not an actual practice on a single farm. Pesticide data from 2018-2020 has been used, originating from the Swiss Agri-Environmental Data Network (SAEDN) (Gilgen et al. 2023). Similarly, farm manure application has been estimated by applying a basic distribution per crop and production system (0% of P2O5 requirement covered with farm manure, based on AGRIDEA 2021) and correcting for the available amount of farm manure in Switzerland that needs to be spread on the cultivated area. The remaining nutrient requirement of the crop is then covered by mineral fertiliser. Machinery operations used for the SALCA emission modelling are taken from  www.labourscope.ch (Accessed: May 2024) ( Groher, T., Heitkämper, K., Umstätter, C. (2020). "Stand der Mechanisierung in der Schweizer Landwirtschaft: Teil 1: Pflanzenproduktion." Agroscope Transfer, 351, 2020, 1-123.), an application for calculating the working-time requirement of labour and production processes (www. www.labourscope.ch (Accessed: May 2024).ch). For the respective inventory modelling, ecoinvent field work processes are used.

Production volume: 2.7444326E7 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop. A non-hibernating green manure crop is modelled between harvest of the previous crop and soil cultivation of the current crop. Included inputs are seeds (crop and green manure), mineral fertilizer and plant protection products. Activities of soil cultivation, sowing, fertilizer application, farm manure spreading, pest and pathogen control, weed control and harvest are included. Irrigation is included as well.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and transport to the farm gate (2km). Storage and drying of harvest goods/grains not included.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Switzerland
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2017
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 2017-2023: Yield data have been collected for the years 2017-2021. For Fertilisation, data sources are taken from the years 2017-2022, Pesticide data are used from the years 2018-2020, and Machinery and workprocess data from 2018.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Durum wheat grain, conventional, national average, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as seed, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory is 'harvest to harvest'. Fertilizers (K, P and organic N) have been adjusted in order to account for the whole rotation.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest as 'drying', 'sorting' or 'storing', even if they happen on farm.
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of fresh matter of durum wheat (15% moisture), conventional production. 
Raw datas comes from:The data is based on literature and statistical data as well as expert judgements. 
Transformation has been performed (weightening and assignments of the flows as well as calculation of direct field emissions).

activityName: Cucumber {GLO}| cucumber production, in heated greenhouse | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Cucumber {GLO}| cucumber production, in heated greenhouse | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents cucumber production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 200 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 4.9 months.

Greenhouse production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 57559834624 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.3 month and it's use of electricity. It also includes the electricity use in the greenhouse. And an average amount of heating energy for the production and the seedling production is included. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included.  
The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

Sugar, from sugar beet {GLO}| market for | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Sugar, from sugar beet {GLO}| market for sugar, from sugar beet | Cut-off, S

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'sugar, from sugar beet', in the Global geography.

Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.

The product 'sugar, from sugar beet' is a processed agricultural product. The multioutput-process 'sugar beet, in sugar refinery' delivers the co-products 'sugar, from sugar beet, at sugar refinery' and 'molasses, from sugar beet, at sugar refinery' and 'pulps, from sugar beet, at sugar refinery'. Sweet juice is extracted from the sugar beets by diffusion. The juice is then purified and crystallized to sugar. Molasses come as a by-product of the crystallization process.

Production volume: 39287382016 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'sugar, from sugar beet',  within the geography of Global.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the supply of 'sugar, from sugar beet',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.

activityName: Sugar, from sugarcane, at sugar refinery {GLO} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: This multi-output process covers the production of sugar from sugarcane (0.1223 kg), and, as co-products, the production of bagasse from sugarcane (0.0191 kg), ethanol from sugarcane fermentation (0.0090 kg) and vinasse from sugarcane fermentation (0.0938 kg). The functional unit is the production of 1 kg sugar from sugarcane.

Allocation: Based on economic allocation: sugar (84.3%), bagasse (0.3%), ethanol (4.6%) and vinasse (10.8%). Allocation is done according to carbon balance for CO2 emissions.

System Boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. This multi-output process covers the production of sugar, bagasse, ethanol and vinasse. The inventory includes the transport of sugarcane to the sugar refinery and the processing of sugarcane to sugar, ethanol (95% w/w), bagasse (79% dry matter, excess), and vinasse from ethanol production. System boundary is at the sugar refinery. Treatment of waste effluents is not included (most wastewater is spread over the fields nearby). Packaging is not included.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 3.0, Good quality

Geography: Global average, extrapolated from Brazilian practice.

Technology: Juice extraction is performed through milling (not diffusion). The juice is then purified and crystallized to sugar according to standard processes. Ethanol is produced by standard fermentation and distillation techniques. Energy supply is done by combustion of the bagasse resulting from the extraction stage. The two main products are sugar and ethanol.

Time: Data from 1994 to 2006, current technology for the production of ethanol from sugarcane

Data sources:
- Weidema B.P., Bauer C., Hischier R., Mutel C., Nemecek T., Reinhard J., Vadenbo C.O., Wernet G. (2013). Overview and methodology. Data quality guideline for the ecoinvent database version 3. Ecoinvent Report 1(v3). St. Gallen: The ecoinvent Centre

activityName: Sugar, from sugar beet, at sugar refinery {GLO} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: This multi-output process covers the production of sugar from sugar beet (0.1569 kg), and, as co-products, the production of sugar beet pulp (0.2040 kg) and molasses from sugar beet (0.0359 kg). The functional unit is the production of 1 kg sugar from sugar beet.

Allocation: Based on economic allocation with 70.2% to sugar, 27.9% to pulp and 1.9% to molasses.

System Boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. This multi-output process covers the production of sugar, molasses and pulp. The inventory includes the transport of sugar beet to the sugar refinery, and the processing of sugar beet to sugar, molasses (72% dry matter) and pulp (25.6% dry matter). System boundary is at the sugar refinery. Treatment of waste effluents is included. Packaging of the sugar is not included.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7, Good quality

Geography: Global average, extrapolated from Swiss practice.

Technology: Sweet juice is extracted from the sugar beets by diffusion. The juice is then purified and crystallized to sugar. Molasses come as a by-product of the crystallization process.

Time: Data from 1998 to 2005, typical technology for the production of sugar from sugar beet

Data sources:
- Weidema B.P., Bauer C., Hischier R., Mutel C., Nemecek T., Reinhard J., Vadenbo C.O., Wernet G. (2013). Overview and methodology. Data quality guideline for the ecoinvent database version 3. Ecoinvent Report 1(v3). St. Gallen: The ecoinvent Centre

Rice, basmati {IN}| rice production, basmati | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Rice, basmati {IN}| rice production, basmati | Cut-off, U

Adaptation for Agribalyse :
Water for irrigation and water emission to air and water is updated according to Ecoinvent 3.10 process
_________________________________

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of Rice Basmati during May- October, 2016 at a farm located in Village-Sawant, District-Kurukshetra of Harayana. In this area, fields are irrigated with ground water using electric pump for surface irrigation. The farm has a Yield_ of 4000 kg fresh matter per ha for this crop cycle. Sowing date for the crop is 29-July, 2016 and harvesting date is 02-October, 2016. Mineral NPK fertilizer input is 137.5-57.5-84 kg/ha. Herbicides used has active ingredient of Butachlor 750g/ha, Insecticides used has active ingredients of Chlorpyrifos 500g/ha, Chlorantraniliprole 4.8g/ha, and Fenpropathrin 775g/ha. Active ingredient proxies used are: Alachlor for Butachlor, Clothianidin for Chlorantraniliprole, and Deltamethrin for Fenpropathrin. Machinery is used only for soil cultivation with fuel consumption of 44.93 kg/ha using plough, rotary cultivator for soil tillage and other activities.

Production volume: 8769999872 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts about four weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in first week of May and sowing of seeds started about eight weeks after soil preparation. Thereafter the crop is mature for harvesting in about 3 months.
Included activities end: The activity ends with the harvesting of the mature Basmati Rice plant. Thereafter the field is prepared for cultivation of the next crop.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for India
Technology level: Current
Technology: Cultivation of Rice Basmati follows conventional production standards
Start date: 01/01/2015
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: 04-May, 2016; Harvesting date main crop: 02-October, 2016. The soil cultivation, sowing and harvesting dates are taken as the middle date of the week or fortnight told to the data collector by the farmer. Total time from date of sowing to date of harvesting comes to 100 days.  The data is collected for one crop cycle. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoeditor.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. comment:

_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Hazelnuts in shell at the farm. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per hectare and year: 1.45574 t/ha, obtained under irrigated conditions (total  amount of water 1541.0 m3/ha). 

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, and seeds, as well as field work processes and the associated diesel combusted in agricultural machinery. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for sprinkler irrigation. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are included.

Data quality rating(DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality)

Geography: Italy

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2002 - 2017

Data sources: 
- Yield: FAOstats average over the years 2013 - 2017
- Tree density, orchard lifetime and mineral fertilizers: Agrion, Fondazione per la ricerca l'innovazione e lo sviluppo tecnologico dell'agricoltura piemontese. Il nocciolo in Piemonte, Linee techniche 2016. Consulted in August 2019 on https://www.nocciolare.it/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Linee-guida-2016-Agrion.pdf
- Irrigation: Bignami, C., Cristofori, V. Scossa, A., Bertazza, G. (2002). Effetto dell'irrigazione sulla composizione della nocciola. 2e Convegno Nazionale sul Nocciolo, pp.206 - 212.
- Machinery fuel (diesel) and pest management: average between data from Iran: Sabzevari, A., Kouchaki-Penchah, H. and Nabavi-Pelesaraei, A. (2015). Investigation of Life Cycle Assessment of Hazelnut Production in Guilan Province of I.R. Iran Based on Orchards size Levels. Biological Forum - An International Journal, pp.807 - 813., and from the Unites States: Julian, J.W., Seavert, C.F., Olsen, J.L., (2008). Orchard Economics: The costs and returns of establishing and producing hazelnuts in the Willamette Valley. Oregon State University, Extension Service. Consulted in August 2019 on http://arec.oregonstate.edu/oaeb/files/pdf/EM8748-E.pdf
- Husk residue management (biowaste): Gürdil GAK, Özcan Baz Y, Demirel B, Demirel C (2016) Pelleting hazelnut husk residues for biofuel. 6th International Conference on Trends in Agricultural Engineering.

Included processes: The inventory includes : all activites of a beef farm, that is (1) all inputs as livestock (young animal), feeds, straw, water (watering and cleaning), fuels and energy as well as the transport to the farm; (2) the buildings and housings as well as infrastructure for milking; (3) the enteric emissions as well as emissions due to the effluent management
The temporal border of the inventory is 'from the birth of the animal to its leaving of the farm'.
Cut-off rule/Exclusion: The inventory does not include vet products and cares, artificial insemination process, small cleaning material and all processes occuring outside of the farm (slaughtering, processing, conservation etc).
This LCI include a water footprint calculation, according to the AGRIBALYSE 2 water scarcity assessment project. For more information about the method, see ADEME. MARTIN Edith (Quantis). 2018. Agribalyse ® 2  empreinte eau : rapport méthodologique. 
WARNING : only the direct water footprint of the animals is calculated here. The feedstuff doesn't contain a full water footprint evaluation. The user should be very careful about the interpretation of the results as the water footprint is not calculated on the full life cycle.
Remark: AGRIBALYSE - product declaration.
Refers to 1 kg (live weight) of beef cattle, national average.

Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1 (very good): >=95%

activityName: Heat, central or small-scale, natural gas {Europe without Switzerland}| market for heat, central or small-scale, natural gas | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Heat, central or small-scale, natural gas {Europe without Switzerland}| market for heat, central or small-scale, natural gas | Cut-off, S

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'heat, central or small-scale, natural gas', in the geography of Europe without Switzerland.

The shares of heat supplying activities with combined heat and power (CHP) plants and pure heat power plants have been estimated. On a small level, more heat is produced in heat plants than in CHP plants. The shares are assumed to amount to 25% heat from CHP plants and 75% heat from heat plants. The shares of the individual supplying activities do not correspond to reality and will have to be refined in future. 

This product represents heat measured in MJ. The heat is produced through the burning of natural gas in heat and power co-generation units and several types of boilers. The dataset is targeted for central or small-scale heating.

Production volume: 5742101266432 MJ
Included activities start: This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'heat, central or small-scale, natural gas',  within the geography of Europe without Switzerland.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the supply of  heat, central or small-scale, natural gas', to the consumers of this product. Transport or losses are considered irrelevant for this product.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe without Switzerland
Technology level: Current
Technology: 
Start date: 01/01/2011
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: electronic component, passive, unspecified//[GLO] market for electronic component, passive, unspecified
Cull cow, conventional, highland milk system, grass fed, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : The inventory includes : all activites of a cattle farm, that is (1) all inputs as livestock (young animal), feeds, straw, water (watering and cleaning), fuels and energy as well as the transport to the farm; (2) the buildings and housings as well as infrastructure for milking; (3) the enteric emissions as well as emissions due to the effluent management
The temporal border of the inventory is 1 year of production
This LCI include a water footprint calculation, according to the AGRIBALYSE 2 water scarcity assessment project. For more information about the method, see ADEME. MARTIN Edith (Quantis). 2018. Agribalyse ® 2  empreinte eau : rapport méthodologique. 
WARNING : only the direct water footprint of the animals is calculated here. The feedstuff doesn't contain a full water footprint evaluation. The user should be very careful about the interpretation of the results as the water footprint is not calculated on the full life cycle.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include vet products and cares, artificial insemination process, small cleaning material and all processes occuring outside of the farm (slaughtering, processing, conservation etc).
Refers to 1 kg of FPC cow milk or 1 kg (live weight) of 13 days calf or 1 kg (live weight) of cull cow
Allocation to the coproducts milk, cull cow and calf has been performed using the biophysical allocation approach (see Koch and Salou 2014).
  Calf : 70.71% of 13 days old calf + 4.43% of diary cow stages
  Cull cow : 29.29% of 13 days old calfs stage + 100% of the four heifer stages
  Milk : 95.57% of diary cow stage
Remark: Functional unit:Refers to 1 kg of FPC cow milk or 1 kg (live weight) of 13 days calf or 1 kg (live weight) of cull cow
Coproducts: 16.902704 Calf for fattening (weight 60,5 kg), 155323.395439968 kg  Milk, 7.0 Cull dairy cow (weight 725 kg)

"The SALCA process ""Sunflower oil, at oil mill/kg/CH"" is used as a proxy to model Sunflower oil extraction at oil mill.

activityName: Syrup, maple, at processing {CA} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset is a result of a collaboration between the Groupe AGECO (corporate responsibility firm located in Quebec, Canada) and the Quebec Maple Syrup Producers (QMSP) since 2012. This was perform for the development of knowledge regarding the environmental impact of the maple syrup production in order to implement effective reduction measures
Included processes: This dataset includes the tapping of the maple trees, the collection of sap through a tubing system to the sugar shack, the fertilization of the trees, the processing of the sap through reverse osmosis and evaporation to obtain 66°Brix maple syrup, cleaning of equipment, filtration and purification and pasteurization
Remark: Inventory refers to the production of 1 kg of maple syrup
Geography: Data is from various maple grove and maple syrup producers in Quebec
Technology: The tubing system functions through pressure differential and pumping. The dataset was modeled for osmosis concentrator and all types of evaporators found in the sugar shack (wood, chip, pellets, oil, combined, electric, propane and natural gas)
Time period: Data from 2015 to 2021 for the current technology and system described. The 2021 season of the Quebec producers from QMSP is used for the current modeling
Production volume: Production of maple syrup was 122 177 150 lbs in Quebec for the 2021 season

activityName: Apple, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Included processes: The inventory includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the orchard, i.e. fertiliser and pesticide application, mulching, harvesting and irrigation. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on the farm. Direct field emissions from crop production activities and from land use change are considered. The establishment phase of the orchard, i.e. tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase. 
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of apples. The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year for the reference period of 2009 - 2012: yield (16.783 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 12249 m3/ha). System boundary: an average year of the productive phase is regarded; included are also the per year of lifetime calculated emissions for nursery, materials for planting, establishment and clearing phase; at farm without storage. Number of years from planting to clearing (lifetime): 15 years   - Waste treatment after clearing of the orchard: Wooden posts and tree wood go to incineration, concrete posts go to land fill, iron wires go to recycling. The data are representative for apple production in China used for the export market.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.5 (i.e. good quality)

Technology: Conventional production

activityName: Winter pea, conventional, 15% moisture, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as seed, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory is 'harvest to harvest'. Fertilizers (K, P and organic N) have been adjusted in order to account for the whole rotation.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest as 'drying', 'sorting' or 'storing', even if they happen on farm.
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of fresh matter of winter pea (15% moisture), conventional production.

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Rye grain, feed, Swiss integrated production {CH}| rye grain, feed production, Swiss integrated production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg processed feedstuff (fresh weight).

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Production volume: 9734000 kg
Included activities start: From reception of rye grain at the factory gate.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the production of feedstuff. The dataset includes the feedstuff processing (crushing or milling, heat treatment, dosing, mixing squeezing and pelleting), storage of the feed mixes,  water use, wastewater treatment, transformation and use of land related to the storage buildings. The dataset doesn't include process air emissions, transport of the feedstuff to the regional storehouse, solid waste generation neither packaging.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Switzerland
Technology level: Current
Technology: The values are valid for pelleted and expanded feedstuffs, and are applied to all cereals and maize. The main steps to process feedstuffs comprise of rolling, crushing or milling, heat treatment, dosing, mixing, squeezing and pelleting. The feed-milling and treatment processes were described in detail by Rossel (2001). The packaging materials are not considered in the datasets.

References

Rossel, U. (2001) Futtermüllerei: die wichtigsten Verfahren. Interner Bericht FAL Reckenholz, Zürich, 6p.

activityName: Rice, non-basmati {CN}| rice production, non-basmati | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Rice, non-basmati {CN}| rice production, non-basmati | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of rice grains, at standard water content required for storage (13.1%). The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 6.6 t/ha. The data are representative for a double rice cropping system in Southern China (Hunan province), representing the largest rice-producing province of China. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 72-23-26 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 3.55 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The share of rice produced in China amounts to 28% of the global production (tonnage produced in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing rice produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:

 - rice production, CN, 2009 - 2012 (18a7fdeb-0fa4-4d9b-a4b7-c96037c23593)]

Production volume: 211090817024 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of rice grains and subsequent burning of crop residues. A winter fallow is following the harvest of late rice, where no irrigation is applied. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: rotary tillage, the application of pesticides and fertilizers, irrigation and harvesting, and on-farm transport. Rice seedlings are transplanted manually by throwing the seedlings in the standing water. Paddy rice is grown under flooded conditions (~40-50 mm water depth) for the entire growing season except for the aeration stage and one week prior to harvest (i.e. ~80 days under flooded conditions per crop cycle). Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. In the considered region of China, rice is produced in a double rice cropping system (two crop cycles). Therefore, an average of the two crop cycles was used for the considered inputs. The inputs of seeds, irrigation water, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include a) grain drying, as no information was available and b) the production of rice seedlings (seeds are used as input). 
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

activityName: This process is not linked to a Brightway activity
Tap water {Europe without Switzerland}| market for | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Tap water {Europe without Switzerland}| market for tap water | Cut-off, S

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'tap water', in the geography of Europe without Switzerland.

Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.

Production volume: 478151998177280 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts from tap water, under pressure, at tap water treatment plant and fed into the tap water distribution network.
Included activities end: This activity ends with 1 kg of water at consumer (industrial or household).

This dataset includes: 
 - the distribution network
 - water losses during transmission 

This dataset doesn"t include
 - energy used during distribution for additional pressure. The tap water is already under pressure when fed into the network (see corresponding tap water production datasets). The implicit assumption is that no additional energy is required during distribution to overcome loss of load in the distribution network. This assumption is not always correct.
 - emissions to groundwater associated with water leaving the distribution network through leaks. These are assumed to be inconsequential since we are dealing with treated tap water.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe without Switzerland
Technology level: Current

activityName: Polypropylene, granulate {RER}| production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Polypropylene, granulate {RER}| polypropylene production, granulate | Cut-off, S

The dataset represents the production mix of commercial PP production technologies: slurry suspension polymerisation,Bulk suspension polymerisation, gas phase polymerisation using Ziegler-Natta and Metallocene catalysts

PP is usually manufactured with the gas phase or the suspension (slurry) process. Modern suspension processes, however, use liquid monomers instead of a solvent and are termed bulk process.

In the gas phase processes a fluidised bed of polymer particles and catalyst is maintained by a steady gaseous monomer feed from the bottom of the reactor. Polymer powder is continuously extracted at the bottom of the fluidised bed reactor. Unreacted monomer gas from the top is compressed and recycled to the reactor inlet. Catalyst, and co-catalyst if necessary, is also continuously fed to the reactor. Typically Ziegler-Natta catalysts are used for gas phase polymerisation where the catalyst is supported on inert silica particles so that the reaction takes place at the catalyst surface.

The suspension polymerisation can be described as precipitation process. The formation of the polymer takes place in a hydrocarbon diluent and under conditions, where the monomer is soluble in the solution. The precipitated polymer, however, is insoluble and forms a fine suspension. The polymer is then separated by centrifugation. The suspension process can be combined with a stirred tank reactor or a loop reactor. Different diluents can be chosen, like C5 to C9 hydrocarbons, hexane, or isobutane.

The bulk suspension process describes the slurry suspension process used for the production of PP where the monomer propylene is used as solvent instead of other hydrocarbons. Modern suspension processes for the production of PP use liquid monomers instead of gaseous.

After the reaction phase, most of the residual (unreacted) monomers (which are mostly present as gases) are separated from the polymer and are either recycled back into the process or flared of. Depending on the purity of the separated monomers, the gas can either be fed directly back into the production line or the monomers are returned to a purification unit. To limit the accumulation of impurities in the process, usually a small side-stream (purge) of the unreacted gas is sent back to the cracker or to a dedicated purification unit. After polymerisation, the polymer is usually fed di-rectly into a hot melt extruder, where additives can be added to the melted polymer if required. The polymer is then pelletised in an underwater pelletiser. The pelletised product is dried, blended where required and degassed.

Production volume: 11000000512 kg
Included activities start: Acitivity starts with monomers and comonomers entering the polymerisation plant. Energy supply is included in terms of heat production inside the battery limits of the plant. Steam and electricity supply is outside the activity.
Included activities end: Activity ends with polymer granulate leaving the factory.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe
Technology level: Current
Technology: Coverage of production capacity in Europe: 76%
Start date: 01/01/2011
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Data was collected for the year 2011, processed in 2013 and published in 2014
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Fish products mackerel, ambient, 169g | Packaging System, N0, All, Aluminium can {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

N0, all Identification key for packaging system containing one or more element.
For more information, please refer to the methodological report  : Colombin, M., Audoye, P., Farrant, L., Allain, D., Anneraud, C., Bosque, F., Besnier, A., Bozec, A.(2024). Rapport méthodologique : volet emballages Agribalyse 3.2.

The inventory refers to an aluminium can and the associated elements allowing to condition a total weight of 169 g (size) of fish products mack (ambient).
This inventory of packaging solution can only be used for products in sub-category "fish product mackerel (ambient)" (PACK_AGB) : refer to the report for more details. This inventory cannot be used to represent the same type of packaging for other products outside the sub-category "fish product mackerel (ambient)" (PACK_AGB) 

The data was produced from study of packaging on the French market (supermarket reference), weighing and CTCPA packaging expertise.
The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. ***Application of CCF, rate of virgin and recycled materials corresponding to the FR scenario (2022) 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

The packaging solutions developed as part of the PACK_AGB project have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html 

Overall data quality : DQR= 2; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 3; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1
Time period: the data describing the packaging solution was collected over the period 2020-2022. 
The inventory is modelled for France. Packaging waste management is representative of packaging waste management in France. 
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".  
Property data : ADEME

_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of fresh agaricus bisporus mushrooms. 

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes the substrate production, the inoculation with mycellium, the growing chambers disinfection, soil covering (peat), the chambers temperature and humidity control (water and energy consumption) and the growing producess (water and pesticides). The direct emissions from peat are included. 
The infrastructure are excluded as well as the mushroom packaging. The spent substrate is considered to be used in agricultural systems (cut-off). 

Geography: the Netherlands. The main reference used is for Spain but the dataset is adapted to a production in the Netherlands changing the electricity mix and water regionalization. 

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2010-2014

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2, Very good quality

activityName: Atlantic Mackerel, Scomber scombrus, NEA, Pelagic Trawl, average, at landing {NL} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 2 boats fishing for mackerel in the Northeast Atlantic (pelagic trawl).

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant le maquereau au chalut pélagique en Atlantique Nord-Est.
Fishery description : French trawlers fishing for mackerel in the Northeast Atlantic are 85 meters long ships. They are registered in Fecamp (FR) but are based and land in Ijmuiden (NL) and Scheveningen (NL). They go out for 15 days trips and spend approximately 225 days at sea per year. This ships are set to fish throughout the entire Northeast Atlantic, from Scotland to the Azores. They use the pelagic trawl technique and land other pelagic species such as herring, horse-mackerel or blue whiting. Mackerel is landed whole and frozen.
Stock status : The Northeast Atlantic mackerel stock is considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,53 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 7,84E-08 (100% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Hazelnuts in shell at the farm. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per hectare and year: 1.27 t/ha, obtained in non-irrigated conditions. 

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, and seeds, as well as field work processes and the associated diesel combusted in agricultural machinery. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for planting. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are included. The main data of the research were collected from 64 randomly selected, conventional hazelnut producers in the Terme district of Samsun province, Turkey, during the production period 20042005. No irrigation was considered based on a confidential source.

Data quality rating(DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality)

Geography: Turkey

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2008 - 2017

Data sources:
- Yield: FAOstat average over the years 2013 - 2017
- Mineral, organic fertilizers and lime: Demiryurek, K., and Cyhan, V. (2008) Economics of organic and conventional hazelnut production in the Terme district of Samsun, Turkey. Renewable Agriculture and Food Systems, pp.217 - 227. doi: 10.1017/S1742170508002251.
- Machinery fuel (diesel) and pest management: Sabzevari, A., Kouchaki-Penchah, H. and Nabavi-Pelesaraei, A. (2015). Investigation of Life Cycle Assessment of Hazelnut Production in Guilan Province of I.R. Iran Based on Orchards size Levels. Biological Forum - An International Journal, pp.807 - 813.
- Husk residue management (biowaste): Gürdil GAK, Özcan Baz Y, Demirel B, Demirel C (2016) Pelleting hazelnut husk residues for biofuel. 6th International Conference on Trends in Agricultural Engineering.

activityName: Linseed {RoW}| linseed production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Linseed {RoW}| linseed production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 8.329e+8 kg

CA: PV = 5.526e+8 kg; weight = 0.6635

RU: PV = 2.803e+8 kg; weight = 0.3365

The comments below were part of the CA regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of linseed grains. The average Yield_ from 2003-2004 is 1.3 t/ha at standard water content required for storage (10%). The data are representative for linseed production in western Canada used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-10-0 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 4 m3/ha of liquid manure and 3 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 1.69 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of linseed grains produced in Canada amounts to 59% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing linseed grains produced in Canada for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 1231968256 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of grains at farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include a) emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production and b) drying due to lack of data.
