activityName: Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 8.000e+9 kg

IN: PV = 6.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.75

US: PV = 2.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.25

Yield of the global dataset = 28125 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the IN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg mint. The average Yield_ from 1999 is 16.5 t/ha. The data are representative for mint production in India, Uttar Pradesh, used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 160-50-50 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.74 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing mint produced in India for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 8000000000 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing seedlings, i.e. seedlings from roots.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the clearing of the field (removing of mint plants). The dataset includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the field including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (4 years), and the clearing of the field. 
The establishment phase of the field includes seedlings nursery, soil cultivation, planting, herbicide use and irrigation.
The productive phase of the field includes machine operations, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting, transport on farm and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the field is cleared by removing the mint plants.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include drying.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology:

End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True

Lemon {ES}| lemon production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Lemon {ES}| lemon production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of lemons. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 37 t/ha. The data are representative for lemons production in Spain used for the export market. §

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of lemons produced in Spain amounts to 16% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing lemons produced in Spain for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.3 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 674371008 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (30 years, 256 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers (mineral and organic) and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.

Technology: Conventional production

activityName: European Pilchard, Sardina pilchardus, BBiscay, Seine, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 13 boats fishing for sardine in the Bay of Biscay (seine)

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant la sardine à la bolinche dans le Golfe de Gascogne.
Fishery description : In France, sardine is fished in the Bay of Biscay by 15 to 20 meters long ships. They are mainly based in Saint-Guénolé, Concarneau and Douarnenez but a few units are present around Bayonne. They go out at night for 8 to 10 hours fishing trips and spend between 150 and 200 days at sea per year. Their fishing area is off the French Atlantic coasts. They use the seine technique and land other pelagic species such as mackerel, anchovy and horse-mackerel. Sardines are landed whole and fresh in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : The Bay of Biscay sardine stock is considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,34 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 3,73E-07 (94,7% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).
Refers to : Average annual activity of boats fishing for sardine in the Bay of Biscay (seine).

activityName: Vanilla {MG}| vanilla production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Vanilla {MG}| vanilla production | Cut-off, U

This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse to represent Vanilla production in Madagascar (recommandations from CIRAD, 2022).
- no mecanisation
- lower Yield_ 
- no land use change
- negative metal emissions have been set to 0
_________________

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of vanilla. The average Yield_ from 2013 is 750 kg/ha. The data are representative for vanilla production in Madagascar used for the export market. No mineral NPK fertiliser are applied. No organic fertilisers are applied. No pesticides are applied.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of vanilla produced in the Madagascar could not be assessed within this project. The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing vanilla produced in the Madagascar for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 2888000 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery of vanilla plants.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of vanilla at farm gate. The dataset includes all activities of a year in the productive phase (8 years) and transport on farm. Activities in the establishment phase (3 years) include manual planting. Activities in the productive phase include harvest of vanilla plants. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The dataset doesn't include a) irrigation, fertilisers or pesticides, because they are not applied due to extensive production where cultivation is done mainly manually b) materials for the planting, establishment and clearing phase, and c) drying because vanilla is dried at ambient temperature. Direct field emissions in this prodcution system are not caused by fertilizer or pesticide inputs from humjan activity but are related to deposition of nutrients, nutrient content of the soil and erosion.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Madagascar
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production

End date: 31/12/2022

activityName: Potato starch {GLO}| market for | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Potato starch {GLO}| market for potato starch | Cut-off, S

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'potato starch', in the Global geography.

In this market, expert judgement was used to develop product specific transport distance estimations.

The product 'potato starch' is a processed agricultural product with a water content of 20% by weight. The production steps include washing of the potatoes, chopping, separation of the potato fruit water, washing, refinering and finally drying of the starch.

Production volume: 4 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'potato starch',  within the geography of Global.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the supply of 'potato starch',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.

activityName: Potato, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Translated name: Potato, at farm (WFLDB 3.5)
Included processes: The inventory includes the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, pesticide application, fertilisation and harvest. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on farm. Inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, irrigation and seeds are included. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are considered.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of potato. The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year, from 2003 - 2013 (15.5 t/ha) produced under irrigated conditions (921 m3/ha total water). The data are representative for potato production in from northwest China, which is not representative for export.
Comment: Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.5 (i.e. good quality)

This dataset represents the production process of refined sunflower oil produced in France.  

Included processes: This process includes the partial dehulling, crushing of sunflower seeds, oil extraction by solvent and refining of crude sunflower oil. Transport of inputs are considered. System boundary is at the oil mill.
Remark: Inventory refers to the production of 1 kg refined sunflower oil, respectively 1,286 kg of sunflower oil cake, fatty acids, deodorization condensates, sunflower hulls from 2,55 kg of sunflower seeds.

Economic value from AGRIBALYSE 1.4 dataset ""Sunflower hulls, low dehulling, animal feed, at transformation plant/FR U"" for Sunflower hulls : 0,08/kg. 
Geography: Data from the ACéVOL study (FNCG and ITERG, 2012), collected from French industrial sites, considered representative of national production.
Technology: Typical oil mill designed for sunflower oil solvent extraction, with pre-pressing of sunflower seeds, and refining of crude sunflower oil, French context.
Time period: Data from 2010, current technology in FR

Source : FNCG, ITERG (2012). ACéVOL - Analyse de Cycle de Vie pour les Oléagineux. Détermination de linformation environnementale des huiles de colza et de tournesol dites « de références »

activityName: Carrot {RoW}| carrot production | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Carrot {RoW}| carrot production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 1.667e+10 kg

CN: PV = 1.590e+10 kg; weight = 0.9539

NL: PV = 5.088e+8 kg; weight = 0.03052

IL: PV = 2.599e+8 kg; weight = 0.01559

Yield of the global dataset = 35996.3522492 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the CN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of carrots. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 35 t/ha. The data are representative for carrot production in China used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 130-40-40 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 6 m3/ha of liquid manure and 5 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 4.3 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of carrots produced in China amounts to 23% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing carrots produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.8 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 18370729984 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of the carrots and their transport to the farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

activityName: Gadidae, CelticSea, Bottom Trawl, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 33 boats fishing for gadidae in the Celtic Sea (bottom trawl).

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant les gadidés au chalut de fond en mer Celtique.
Fishery description : In France, gadidae (cod, whiting and haddock) are fished in the Celtic Sea by 16 to 32 meters long ships. They are mainly based in Brittany, in Le Guilvinec or Paimpol. They go out for 10-15 days fishing trips and spend between 200 and 300 days at sea per year. Their fishing area corresponds to the entire Celtic Sea. They use the twin bottom trawl technique and land other benthic species such as anglerfishes, rays or cuttlefish. Gadidae are landed gutted and fresh (conversion ratio : cod : 1,17 - haddock : 1,17 - whiting : 1,18) in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : The Celtic Sea cod stock is considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,26 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
	      The Celtic Sea whiting stock is not considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 0,83 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1).
	      The Celtic Sea haddock stock is considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,68 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1).
Pressure on stocks indicator : 4,28E-06 (82,9% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).
Refers to : Average annual activity of benthic trawlers fishing for gadidae in the Celtic Sea (bottom trawl).
Geography : France.
Version : 1.0.
Energy values : Net values
Percent representativeness : 0
Production volume : Unknown

Geographical representativeness (GR) = 1 (very good): >=95%

Completeness (C) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 3 (fair): >75% and <=85%
Methodological appropriateness and consistency (M) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Final note = 2,3 (basic quality).
Coproducts : None.
Allocation : Mass allocation.
Background data: All background data originates from ecoinvent 3.3
Technology : Modern.

 This process describes the average consumption mix of Squid in France.

For all fish data are based on expert say.
The share of domestic production is 40%, while the remainder is split equitably between EU import (refrigerated truck transport per 1,000 km) and non-EU import (refrigerated boat transport per 10,000 km)
The mapping with fishing datasets is based on the predominant fishing mode of each species. This work was developed with the help of technical institute (Comité des pêches, Thomas Clotre, April 2019)

activityName: Carrot {RoW}| carrot production | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Carrot {RoW}| carrot production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 1.667e+10 kg

CN: PV = 1.590e+10 kg; weight = 0.9539

NL: PV = 5.088e+8 kg; weight = 0.03052

IL: PV = 2.599e+8 kg; weight = 0.01559

Yield of the global dataset = 35996.3522492 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the CN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of carrots. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 35 t/ha. The data are representative for carrot production in China used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 130-40-40 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 6 m3/ha of liquid manure and 5 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 4.3 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of carrots produced in China amounts to 23% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing carrots produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.8 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 18370729984 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of the carrots and their transport to the farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

activityName: Blackberry, at farm {RS} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Blackberry at the farm, with standard water content (88.15%). The reference flow is the average Yield_ per hectare and year: 5.93 t/ha, obtained under irrigated conditions (total  amount of water 785 m3/ha). 

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes the processes of seedling production and planting, fertilisation and pesticide application, irrigation and harvest. Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for sprinkler irrigation. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (fertiliser and pesticides) are considered. Irrigation is based on blue water from Pfister for raspberries in Serbia. There is no LUC for raspberries in Serbia and the same is assumed for blackberries.  Fertilizers and manure application is mechanized while pesticides application is assumed to be done manually with manual back sprays. The harvest is assumed to be manual harvesting according to http://www.usz.gov.rs/files/publikacije/FruitIndustryInSerbia.pdf. Number of years from planting to clearing (lifetime): 15 years (Maksimovic 2014).

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2, Very good quality

Geography: Serbia

Technology: Conventional production.

Time: 2008-2014

Data sources: 
Maksimovic 2014: Maksimovic G, Jovanovic R, Mitrovic S, Ivanovic T, 2014. Economic adequacy of blackberry production in rural areas of Sirinic district. Agroznanje, vol 15.  
Strik 2008: Strik B C, Clark J R, Finn C E, Banats M P, 2008. Worlwide production of blackberries.  Acta Hort. 777. 
http://www.usz.gov.rs/files/publikacije/FruitIndustryInSerbia.pdf

activityName: Egg, conventional, indoor system, non-cage, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : The inventory includes: all activities of a poultry farm, that is (1) all inputs as livestock (young animal), feeds, water (watering and clenaning), fuels and energy used for the hatchery as well as the transport to the farm; (2) the buildings and barns; (3) emissions due to the effluent management. 
The border of the inventory is from the birth of the animal to its leaving of the farm.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include vet products and cares, artificial insemination process, small cleaning material and all processes occuring outside of the farm (slaughtering, processing, conservation etc).
Refers to 1 kg of egg or 1 kg (live weight) of cull hen.
Allocation: Allocation to the coproducts egg and cull hen has been performed using the biophysical allocation approach. Eggs : 100% of the laying hens stage. Cull hens : 100% of the future reproductives, reproductives and young hens stages.
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of egg, or 1 kg (live weight) of cull hen, conventional non-cage indoor production
Production of egg with indoor non-cage system.

activityName: Fennel {GLO}| fennel production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents fennel production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 16 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 2.75 months.

Field production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 2.40114694E11 kg
Included activities start: From seedling production.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.75 month and it's use of electricity.  And the greenhouse heating energy for the seedling production.The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Current
Technology: Integrated Production
Start date: 01/01/2010
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Cherry, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
This dataset represents the global average for cherry production, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to faostat data for 2009-2013:
 - USA: 19.4%
 - Turkey: 13.8%
 - Chile: 12.2%
 - Italy: 2.1% 
 
These countries together represent 47.6% of global export.
All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of cherries, at farm.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2, Very good quality

Data source: 
faostat, export data, sum of cherries and cherries sour, 2009-2013

activityName: Soybean {BR}| market for soybean | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Soybean {BR}| market for soybean | Cut-off, U

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'soybean', in the geography of Brazil.

This is dataset represents the transport of 1 kg of soybeans from the production farm to the plant producting soybean meal and soybean oil. No losses are considered in this dataset.

The product 'soybean' is a seed. It is an annual crop. The ecoinvent database also contains this product from organic and Swiss integrated production.

Production volume: 115711918080 kg
Included activities start: The activity starts at the gate of soybean cultivation farm.
Included activities end: The activity ends with the provision of soybean grains to the soybean meal and oil production plant.

Technology level: Current
Technology: The data are intended to reflect current equipment and processes on a Brazilian level.

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Barley grain {FR}| barley production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of barley grain (fresh matter). The Yield_ is 6760 kg/ha at a moisture content at storage of 14%.

None

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Production volume: 10313389056 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop. The inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers and pesticides are considered. It is assumed that no organic fertilisers are applied.
Included activities end: The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvest and transport from field to farm (2 km). Further, direct field emissions are included. This activity ends after harvest at the farm gate.

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Translated name: Clémentine (Nour), qualité export, Souss, sortie verger
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil preparation and cultivation, planting the trees, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest as the demolition of the orchard; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as young plants, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory corresponds to the life cyle of the orchard.
Cut-off rule/Exclusion: The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest (storing) as well as all hand-works if any (e.g. pruning).
Remark: AGRIBALYSE - product declaration.
Refers to 1 kg of clementine, Nour variety, export quality, conventional production.
ILCD - Overall data quality:
Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Completeness (C) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 2 (good): >7% and <=10%
Methodological appropriateness and consistency (M) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Final note = 2,0 (i.e.: basic quality).
Yield: 330600 kg/ha for 25 production years (i.e. average Yield_ of export quality: 13224 kg/ha/yr).
Coproducts: Clementine for the local market (i.e. approx. 40% of the total Yield_)
Allocation: Economic allocation, 14% of the in- and outputs are allocated to the clementine for local market.
All background data originates either from ecoinvent 3.4, INRA or AGRIBALYSE.
Dataset was generated by MEANS-InOut software. Models used : [CO2 Urea - IPCC 2006, tier 1; Inputs transportation : tropics (ecoinvent v3); Water  take off; Land occupation - ecoinvent v2; N2O Indirect - IPCC 2006, tier 1, Energy, in biomass - EcoInventv2, CO2 biogenic - EcoInvent2; Energy consumption; NH3 - EMEP 2016, tier 2; Phytosanitaries - EcoInvent2; P erosion - SALCA-P; NO3 - IPCC 2013, tier1; N2O Direct - IPCC 2006, tier 1; P Leaching - SALCA-P; CO2 Liming - IPCC 2006, tier 1; Erosion - RUSLE simplified - SI units; P Flow - SALCA-P; NO - EMEP 2009, tier 1; ]
Geography: Morocco (Region Souss)
Technology: Conventional production
Time period: Inventory data refers to an orchard in the state of maturity in the year 2010
Energy values: Net values

Production volume: 55,6% of total exports of clementine to France originate from the province Souss whereof the Nour variety is the most representativ variety.

activityName: Rapeseed, at farm {CA} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Translated name: Rapeseed, at farm (adapted from WFLDB)
Included processes: 'The inventory includes the processes of sowing, pesticide application, fertilisation, harvest and grain drying. Tillage practice in western Canada from 2005 were assumed to be representative: full tillage = 24%, conservation tillage = 26%, no tillage = 50%, although no tillage and conservation tillage are likely to be higher now than in 2005. Rapeseeed is normally not irrigated in western Canada. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on farm. Inputs of fertilisers, pesticides and seeds are included. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are considered.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of rapeseed, at standard water content required for storage (8%). The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2009 - 2012 (1.9 t/ha) produced under non-irrigated conditions. Data are representative for canola production in western Canada, that represents 80% of acres in Canada, used for the export market. From the sources used it is not clear, wether data is for GMO or non-GMO canola. About 90% of canola in Canada is genetically modified (herbicide-resistance).

Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.2 (i.e. excellent quality)

Technology: Conventional production
Version: 2.2
Energy values: Undefined
Local category: Landwirtschaftliche Produktion
Local subcategory: Pflanzenbau

The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

activityName: Winter pea, conventional, 15% moisture, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as seed, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory is 'harvest to harvest'. Fertilizers (K, P and organic N) have been adjusted in order to account for the whole rotation.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest as 'drying', 'sorting' or 'storing', even if they happen on farm.
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of fresh matter of winter pea (15% moisture), conventional production. 
Raw datas comes from:The data is based on literature and statistical data as well as expert judgements. 
Transformation has been performed (weightening and assignments of the flows as well as calculation of direct field emissions).
PEF  Overall data quality : 
Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2 : Good
Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2 : Good
Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 3 : Fair
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 2 : Good
Final note = 2,25 : Good data quality level
Yield: 3810.0 kg
Coproducts: Straw. Total straw per hectare: 1407 kg DM/ha. The straw is harvested on 23% of the surfaces (i.e. straw valorized = 324 kg DM/ha).. Allocation: No allocation has been performed as the price of straw is not known..

activityName: Cooking, industrial, 1kg of cooked product {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
This dataset is gate-to-gate and models the cooking process of 1 kg of food, by considering an equal-weight average of a frying process, an oven-baking process and a boiling process for 1 kg of food. For the 3 processes, the machineries have been excluded since we consider a lifetime of 10 years for the appliances, and a large batch size.
_Frying : The process includes electricity consumption and cooking oil consumption. It does not include air emissions life-cycle, by lack of data. The appliance life-cycle was excluded from the scope.
_Boiling : The process includes electricity consumption and cooking oil consumption. It does not include air emissions life-cycle, by lack of data.  The appliance life-cycle was excluded from the scope.
The process includes electricity consumption. It excludes air emission due to lack of data. The appliance life-cycle was excluded from the scope.
In the development of Agribalyse 3.0, the upstream life-cycle stages of the food product, downstream life cycle stages and packaging from gate to consumer are added separately.

_Energy consumption : The energy consumption data was found consistent with basic thermal calculations based on BREF generic data. For boiling (blanching), the energy consumption for gas boiling has been averaged between the data presented for potato blanching and the data presented for pasta boiling (Fusi et al., 2016; Wu et al., 2012). For frying, the energy consumption has been extracted from a study on potato frying as French fries (Mouron et al., 2016).
_Additional ingredients : Additional ingredients accounted for are tap water, for boiling, and rapeseed oil, for frying.
_Emissions : Emissions to air (water from boiling) and emissions to water are included for boiling process
_Waste management : or the frying process, used oil is collected separately to be purified. According to the decree on 12th July 201, the collection of used cooking oil is mandatory in order to recycle it (Legifrance, 2011). In January 2016, the obligation threshold was lowered at 60 tons per year, meaning this obligation is applicable to a large amount of food industries.  We used the ecoinvent dataset: "Used vegetable cooking oil, purified (FR) treatment of used vegetable cooking oil, purification, Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent". The geographical scope for the ecoinvent dataset is French specific and covers all the end of life process: collection, transport, effluent treatment, storage and credits for the recovered oil. Other solid wastes are out of scope (Appliances at end of life and maintenance and cleaning material).
_Transport : we used "market for" datasets already (transportation already included in these datasets). 
_

This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
Translated name: Linseed, at farm (adapted from WFLDB)
Included processes: The inventory includes the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, pesticide application, fertilisation and harvest. Data on drying were not available. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on farm. Inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, irrigation and seeds are included. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are considered.
Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of linseed grains, at standard water content required for storage (10%). The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha (1.3 t/ha)  and year, from 2003-2004 produced under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 387 m3/ha). The data are representative for linseed production in western Canada used for the export market.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality)

activityName: Banana, mixed production, West Indies, at farm gate {WI} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Translated name: Banane, mix de production, Antilles, sortie de ferme 
Included processes: The inventory includes: (1) Consumption of water and nutriments, energy consumption, (2) Pesticides treatment and fertilizer consumption, sodding (3) vitroplant transportation by plane to the West Indies, (4) tree nursery (energy consumption, phytosanitary treatment, and transport to the farm)

The temporal border of the inventory corresponds to the life cyle of the banana plantation.
Cut-off rule/Exclusion: The inventory does not include processes occuring after post-harvest treatments (storing and transportation to mainland France), small material (e.g. cutting blades), production of equipment (trap, pads etc), production, transport and consumption of calcium and magnesium fertilizers, additives for pesticides and packaging of consumables. Cocktail effect from the accumulation of substances are also excluded. 

Refers to 1 kg of fresh matter of banana, mixed production.

ILCD - Overall data quality:
Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2 (good)
Geographical representativeness (GR) = 3 (satisfactory/ acceptable)
Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2 (good)
Completeness (C) =3 (average)
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 3 (acceptable)
Methodological appropriateness and consistency (M) = 2 (good)
Final note = 2.7 (i.e.: basic quality).

Yield: 309516.71 kg/ha for 7 production years (i.e. average Yield_ of 44216.7 kg/ha/yr).

Allocation: No allocation has been performed.
Background data: All background data originates either from ecoinvent 3.1 (Alloc Rec S), INRA or from AGRIBALYSE.

activityName: Canning fruits or vegetables, industrial, 1kg of canned product {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
This dataset is gate-to-gate and covers all stages from peeled fruit or vegetable to canned fruit or vegetable: slicing of fruit or vegetable, can filling and sterilization. It is assumed to take place in France. Consequently, all datasets are chosen for France and Europe, when not available for France.
The figure below represents the life cycle boundaries.
The downstream stages from plant gate to consumer are out of scope, in accordance with the Agribalyse 3.0 methodology. The following stages are excluded from the system:
o The washing of fruit and vegetable prior to canning (excluded in Agribalyse 3.0 LCIs)
o The production and EoLof packaging, included elsewhere in upstream or downstream LCIs in Agribalyse v3.0

The figure represents the system modelling.

A review of bibliography has been done to collect data on canning processes, along with an interview with a French canning process expert. The expert reviewed and validated the data collected from literature. Our research on vegetables led to compiling five studies, calculating the average electricity, steam and water consumption for each step of the canning process. For fruits, we reviewed the data for peach canning, which amounted to a single study (Folinas et al., 2015). The data was considered not robust enough, leading to excluding fruit canning from the scope of the model.
_From the bibliography and the interview with a canning expert, we derived the energy consumptions for the vegetable canning process see section 8. One study provided the total energy consumption for canning (steam and electricity), it was used as a reference (Rao, 1977).  As explained previously, considering that water and steam circulates in a closed loop throughout the process, only the energy for pumping and heating water has been considered in the modelling of the water circuit.
_The canning process involves water and steam consumption. However, according to the data provided by our canning process expert, water and steam are processed within a closed loop. Thus, water consumption for steam, cooling and other processes was not included in the scope. In order to calculate the water quantity in the cans, we calculated an average among data from Openfoodfacts website (Google Play app, 2019)
_In the Cradle to Consumer Life Cycle Greenhouse Gas Accounting of Sweet Corn in Minnesota (Miller, 2017) considers the addition of 7,27 g of salt per kg of canned corn. This value has been adopted after validation by our canning expert.
_The food losses at the sub-steps of the process have not been modelled. The loss are modelled at a global process level. Therefore, a 1% default loss rate is applied at the end of the process. This is a conservative approach since all flows are augmented by 1%. The resulting waste (food, water and salt) are included in the inventory.
_Emissions are related to solid waste due to the global product loss. Consequently, 1% of input food, water and salt are treated at the end of life.
_ Transportation is not modelled in the inventory, as it is already accounted for in the electricity and salt inventories. The electricity inventory is an ecoinvent "market" inventory accounting for electricity transportation, and the salt Acyvia inventory relies on an ecoinvent sodium chloride "market" inventory.
_ The packaging life cycle is not included. The future practitioner will be in charge of adding the appropriate packaging manufacture and end of life, as well as the 1% loss rate related to the canning process.

activityName: Spring faba bean, conventional, reduced protection, at farm gate {FR} U

'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 17055866880 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends after harvest and drying of grains at the farm gate.
The dataset includes the inputs of seeds, mineral and organic fertilisers, pesticides and all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, transport of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides to the field (15 km), sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvesting, transport from field to farm or local drying centre and drying of grains. Direct field emissions are also included. The use of car, van or pick-up for servicing people, e.g. from farm to field, is not included in the activities. Note that there is likely irrigation involved at the GLO scale, but no data were specifically collected for the dataset since it is extrapolated from the QC-CA geography where no irrigation is applied.

activityName: Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 8.000e+9 kg

IN: PV = 6.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.75

US: PV = 2.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.25

Yield of the global dataset = 28125 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the IN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg mint. The average Yield_ from 1999 is 16.5 t/ha. The data are representative for mint production in India, Uttar Pradesh, used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 160-50-50 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.74 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing mint produced in India for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 8000000000 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing seedlings, i.e. seedlings from roots.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the clearing of the field (removing of mint plants). The dataset includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the field including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (4 years), and the clearing of the field. 
The establishment phase of the field includes seedlings nursery, soil cultivation, planting, herbicide use and irrigation.
The productive phase of the field includes machine operations, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting, transport on farm and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the field is cleared by removing the mint plants.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include drying.

Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Production volume: 240114696192 kg
Included activities start: From sowing.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.3 month and it's use of electricity. It also includes the electricity use in the greenhouse. And an average amount of heating energy for the production is included. 
The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Global
Technology level: Current
Technology: Integrated production

activityName: Peanut {RoW}| peanut production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Peanut {RoW}| peanut production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 2.285e+10 kg

CN: PV = 1.586e+10 kg; weight = 0.6941

IN: PV = 6.338e+9 kg; weight = 0.2774

AR: PV = 6.509e+8 kg; weight = 0.02849

Yield of the global dataset = 2759.24309039 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the CN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of peanuts. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 3.5 t/ha. The data are representative for peanut production in China used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 80-27-28 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 11.25 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peanuts produced in China amounts to 10% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peanuts produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 17201534976 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of peanuts at farm gate. The dataset includes total diesel combusted in agricultural machinery, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. 
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology: 
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Cow milk, conventional, national average, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Translated name: Lait de vache, Moyenne nationale (France), sortie atelier
Included processes: The inventory includes : all activites of a cattle farm, that is (1) all inputs as livestock (young animal), feeds, straw, water (watering and cleaning), fuels and energy as well as the transport to the farm; (2) the buildings and housings as well as infrastructure for milking; (3) the enteric emissions as well as emissions due to the effluent management
The temporal border of the inventory is 1 year of production
Cut-off rule/Exclusion: The inventory does not include vet products and cares, artificial insemination process, small cleaning material and all processes occuring outside of the farm (slaughtering, processing, conservation etc).
Remark: AGRIBALYSE - product declaration.
Refers to 1 kg of FPC cow milk, national averge.
ILCD - Overall data quality:
Technological representativeness (TeR) = 4 (poor): >=50% and < 75%
Geographical representativeness (GR) = 1 (very good): >=95%
Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1 (very good): >=95%
Completeness (C) = 3 (fair): >=75% and < 85%
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 3 (fair): >10% and <=15%
Methodological appropriateness and consistency (M) = 3 (fair): >=75% and < 85%
Final note = 3,1 (i.e.: data estimate).
Yield: 7426 kg of FPC milk/animal and year.
Coproducts: Milk, cull cow and calf
Allocation: see base inventories
Background data: All background data orginates either from ecoinvent 3.1 (Alloc Rec S), INRA or from AGRIBALYSE.
Information about direct emission models: Dataset was generated by the AGRIBALYSE Inventory data processing system (IDPS) using version V7.0 of the models for the calculation of the direct emissions (CH4, CO2, ETM, NH3, NOx, NO3, N2O, P, Pesticides)
Geography: France
Technology: Average mix of technology for the production of cow milk in France.
Time period: Inventory data based on the period 2005-2009.
Version: 1.40
Energy values: Net values
Production volume: 21,1% of the national production

activityName: Albacore, Thunnus alalunga, NEA, Pelagic trawl, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 16 boats fishing for albacore tuna in the Northeast Atlantic Ocean (pelagic trawl).

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant le thon germon au chalut pélagique dans l'océan Atlantique Nord-Est.
Fishery description : In France, albacore tuna is fished in the Northeast Atlantic by 17 to 25m long pelagic trawlers. They leave their home port (mainly St-Nazaire, Lorient, Le Guilvinec and Bayonne) for approximately 10 days, from mid-july to the end of october. Their fishing area extends from Cape Finisterre to the west of Ireland, via the Bay of Biscay. They use the pair-trawling technique and fish other pelagic species such as swordfish or bluefin tuna. Albacore tunas are landed whole and fresh in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : The Northeast Atlantic albacore stock is not considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 0,72 (ICCAT 2013 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 4,03E-08 (99,8% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).
Refers to : Average annual activity of boats fishing for albacore tuna in NEA (pelagic trawl).
Geography : France.
Version : 1.0.
Energy values : Net values
Percent representativeness : 0
Production volume : Unknown
ILCD - Overall data quality :
Technological representativeness (TeR) = 1 (very good): >=95%
Geographical representativeness (GR) = 1 (very good): >=95%
Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Completeness (C) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 3 (fair): >75% and <=85%
Methodological appropriateness and consistency (M) = 2 (good): >=85% and < 95%
Final note = 2,3 (basic quality).
Coproducts : None.
Allocation : Mass allocation.
Background data: All background data originates from ecoinvent 3.3
Technology : Modern.

activityName: Used Li-ion battery {GLO}| market for used Li-ion battery | Cut-off, U
comment:
This is a market activity, representing a treatment mix. In the case of products needing treatment, market mixes are supplied by the activities treating the product in the geography defined by the market, and they supply the activities needing to treat the product, as they have generated it as a by-product in the Undefined processes (present as a negative input in system models). Transport to the treating facility or losses are also accounted in this type of markets, when relevant.

This is the market for  'used Li-ion battery', in the Global geography.

Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.

Production volume: 2000000.0 kg
Included activities start: The activity starts with the input from the treatment processes.
Included activities end: A market for a material for treatment (wastes or recyclables) ends with the provision of treatment, i.e. a mix of treatment providers, to activities that generate the reference product as a waste/by-product.

_________________________________
This dataset represents the global average for banana, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to FAOSTAT data for 2010:
 - Ecuador: 29.5%
 - Costa Rica: 10.5%
 - Colombia: 9.7%
 - India: 0.4%
These countries together represent 50% of global export.
All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of banana.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.0 (i.e. very good quality)

activityName: European Pilchard, Sardina pilchardus, BBiscay, Seine, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 13 boats fishing for sardine in the Bay of Biscay (seine)

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant la sardine à la bolinche dans le Golfe de Gascogne.
Fishery description : In France, sardine is fished in the Bay of Biscay by 15 to 20 meters long ships. They are mainly based in Saint-Guénolé, Concarneau and Douarnenez but a few units are present around Bayonne. They go out at night for 8 to 10 hours fishing trips and spend between 150 and 200 days at sea per year. Their fishing area is off the French Atlantic coasts. They use the seine technique and land other pelagic species such as mackerel, anchovy and horse-mackerel. Sardines are landed whole and fresh in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : The Bay of Biscay sardine stock is considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,34 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 3,73E-07 (94,7% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).
Refers to : Average annual activity of boats fishing for sardine in the Bay of Biscay (seine).

activityName: Raw cow milk archetype, feed mix IT-154, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Dairy farm archetype IT-154 according to FAO, IDF, IFCN (2014).
IT-154 represents an average-sized farm in northern Italy (Lombardy), having Holstein cows with a milk yield of 8 810 kg milk/cow per year. The cows are kept in a free stall barn where milking is done in a parlour system. The farm operates on 72 ha of land that is very fertile and can also be used for cash crops. About 56 percent of the work on the farm is done by family members.

Allocation between milk and meat (live animals) based on bio-physical causality (IDF 2015)
Inventory is for 1 kg raw milk, uncorrected. Mass produced is given for FPCM equivalent (IDF 2015)
Co-product is beef cattle, from dairy farm (culled cows and male calves).

Included: all feed inputs, pasture and pasture-related emissions, enteric emissions.
Excluded: milking, farm infrastructure and energy/water consumption, manure management, packaging, transport for raw milk collection.

Hence the raw milk archetypes datasets are intended to be used in the raw milk national mix datasets, where manure management, farm processes and local peat degradation are also combined. The inventory is presented for 1 kg uncorrected raw milk, but the output quantity is corrected to correspond to 1 kg of FPCM.

1 kg FPCM (fat and protein corrected milk)
1 kg LW (live weight) beef cattle, from dairy farm
Milk yield = 8810 kg year-1 cow-1
Number of dairy cows per farm = 154
Number of heifers per farm = 118 (avg)

Data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 ( i.e. very good quality)

[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Production volume: 4 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop. The inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers and pesticides are considered. Farm manure as an organic fertiliser is only accounted for in terms of direct field emissions; all pre-processes are included in the animal production systems.
Included activities end: The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvest, transport from field to regional processing centre (10 km) and drying of grains. Further, direct field emissions are included. The cultivation of green manure during winter before sowing beans is also included. This activity ends after drying of grains at the regional processing centre.

activityName: Peanut {IN}| peanut production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Peanut {IN}| peanut production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of peanuts. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 1 t/ha. The data are representative for peanut production in India used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-60-0 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.81 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peanuts produced in India amounts to 30% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peanuts produced in India for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 6338124800 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of peanuts at farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for India
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production

activityName: Sweet corn, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
This dataset represents the global average for Sweet corn, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to FAOSTAT data for 2010:
 - Thailand: 25%
 - Hungary: 21%
 - United States: 17%
These countries together represent 63% of global export. 
All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Sweet corn.

Included processes: The inventory includes the processes of soil tillage, sowing, pesticide application, fertilisation and harvest. Drying is not applied systematically (assumption 10% of Yield_ is dried). Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on farm. Inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, irrigation and seeds are included. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are considered.

The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2006 - 2010, which is 2.4 t/ha with an average irrigation of 24 m3 water/ha (4% of the sunflower fields are irrigated irrigated, receiving 600 m3/ha water).  The data are representative for conventional sunflower seed production in France, considering an average of irrigated and non-irrigated fields, used for the export market.

activityName: Rice, basmati {IN}| rice production, basmati | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Rice, basmati {IN}| rice production, basmati | Cut-off, U

Adaptation for Agribalyse :
Water for irrigation and water emission to air and water is updated according to Ecoinvent 3.10 process
_________________________________

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of Rice Basmati during May- October, 2016 at a farm located in Village-Sawant, District-Kurukshetra of Harayana. In this area, fields are irrigated with ground water using electric pump for surface irrigation. The farm has a Yield_ of 4000 kg fresh matter per ha for this crop cycle. Sowing date for the crop is 29-July, 2016 and harvesting date is 02-October, 2016. Mineral NPK fertilizer input is 137.5-57.5-84 kg/ha. Herbicides used has active ingredient of Butachlor 750g/ha, Insecticides used has active ingredients of Chlorpyrifos 500g/ha, Chlorantraniliprole 4.8g/ha, and Fenpropathrin 775g/ha. Active ingredient proxies used are: Alachlor for Butachlor, Clothianidin for Chlorantraniliprole, and Deltamethrin for Fenpropathrin. Machinery is used only for soil cultivation with fuel consumption of 44.93 kg/ha using plough, rotary cultivator for soil tillage and other activities.

Production volume: 8769999872 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts about four weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in first week of May and sowing of seeds started about eight weeks after soil preparation. Thereafter the crop is mature for harvesting in about 3 months.
Included activities end: The activity ends with the harvesting of the mature Basmati Rice plant. Thereafter the field is prepared for cultivation of the next crop.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for India
Technology level: Current
Technology: Cultivation of Rice Basmati follows conventional production standards
Start date: 01/01/2015
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: 04-May, 2016; Harvesting date main crop: 02-October, 2016. The soil cultivation, sowing and harvesting dates are taken as the middle date of the week or fortnight told to the data collector by the farmer. Total time from date of sowing to date of harvesting comes to 100 days.  The data is collected for one crop cycle. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoeditor.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Olive {IT}| olive production | Cut-off, U
comment:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of olives. The average yield from 2001-2008 is 4.3 t/ha. The data are representative for Olive production in Italy (Puglia region or Sicily) used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 75-25-30 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 2 m3/ha of liquid manure and 2 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 16.75 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The share of olives produced in Italy amounts to 16% of the global production (tonnage produced in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing olives produced in Italy for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 3.16426025E9 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (40 years, 250 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Italy
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2001
End date: 31/12/2024
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Time period referring to the data source: 2001-2008. Based on expert opinion data is considered to be valid at least up to 2012.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual
