activityName: European Pilchard, Sardina pilchardus, BBiscay, Seine, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 13 boats fishing for sardine in the Bay of Biscay (seine)

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant la sardine à la bolinche dans le Golfe de Gascogne.
Fishery description : In France, sardine is fished in the Bay of Biscay by 15 to 20 meters long ships. They are mainly based in Saint-Guénolé, Concarneau and Douarnenez but a few units are present around Bayonne. They go out at night for 8 to 10 hours fishing trips and spend between 150 and 200 days at sea per year. Their fishing area is off the French Atlantic coasts. They use the seine technique and land other pelagic species such as mackerel, anchovy and horse-mackerel. Sardines are landed whole and fresh in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : The Bay of Biscay sardine stock is considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,34 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 3,73E-07 (94,7% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).
Refers to : Average annual activity of boats fishing for sardine in the Bay of Biscay (seine).

activityName: Bluefin Tuna, Thunnus thynnus, MedSea, Longline, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 13 boats fishing for bluefin tuna in the Mediterranean sea (longline)

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant le thon rouge à la palangre en mer Méditerranée.
Fishery description : In France, longliners fishing for bluefin tuna in the Mediterranean sea are 9 to 18 meters long ships. They leave their mediterranean home port (Sète, Grau-d'Agde etc...) at the end of the day for a 10 hours fishing trip. Their typical fishing season starts in April and ends around December, with a break during the seine season in June-July. Their fishing area is off the French Mediterranean coast. They use the longlining technique and also fish other species such as swordfish. Bluefin tunas are landed whole and fresh in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : The Mediterranean/Eastern Atlantic bluefin tuna stock is not considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 0,36 (ICCAT 2014 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 5,19E-06 (100% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes :

activityName: Sodium chloride, powder {GLO}| market for | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Sodium chloride, powder {GLO}| market for sodium chloride, powder | Cut-off, S

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.

This is the market for  'sodium chloride, powder', in the Global geography.

Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.

'sodium chloride, powder'  is an inorganic substance with a CAS no. : 007647-14-5. It is called 'sodium chloride' under IUPAC naming and its molecular formula is: NaCl. It is solid under normal conditions of temperature and pressure and appears as a white crystalline solid. It is modelled as a pure substance.  On a consumer level, is used in the following products: cosmetics and personal care products, fertilisers, anti-freeze products, perfumes and fragrances and water treatment chemicals. On industrial sites, the substance is used for the manufacture of products in the following sectors: formulation of mixtures and/or re-packaging, textile, leather or fur, pulp, paper and paper products, chemicals, mineral products (e.g. plasters, cement) and electrical, electronic and optical equipment.

Production volume: 3481869824 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'sodium chloride, powder',  within the geography of Global.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the supply of 'sodium chloride, powder',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.

activityName: Gadidae, CelticSea, Bottom Trawl, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 33 boats fishing for gadidae in the Celtic Sea (bottom trawl).

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant les gadidés au chalut de fond en mer Celtique.
Fishery description : In France, gadidae (cod, whiting and haddock) are fished in the Celtic Sea by 16 to 32 meters long ships. They are mainly based in Brittany, in Le Guilvinec or Paimpol. They go out for 10-15 days fishing trips and spend between 200 and 300 days at sea per year. Their fishing area corresponds to the entire Celtic Sea. They use the twin bottom trawl technique and land other benthic species such as anglerfishes, rays or cuttlefish. Gadidae are landed gutted and fresh (conversion ratio : cod : 1,17 - haddock : 1,17 - whiting : 1,18) in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : The Celtic Sea cod stock is considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,26 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
	      The Celtic Sea whiting stock is not considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 0,83 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1).
	      The Celtic Sea haddock stock is considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,68 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1).
Pressure on stocks indicator : 4,28E-06 (82,9% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).
Refers to : Average annual activity of benthic trawlers fishing for gadidae in the Celtic Sea (bottom trawl).

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 2 boats fishing for herring in the Northeast Atlantic (pelagic trawl).

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant le hareng au chalut pélagique en Atlantique Nord-Est.
Fishery description : French trawlers fishing for herring in the Northeast Atlantic are 85 meters long ships. They are registered in Fecamp (FR) but are based and land in Ijmuiden (NL) and Scheveningen (NL). They go out for 15 days trips and spend approximately 225 days at sea per year. This ships are set to fish throughout the entire Northeast Atlantic, from Scotland to the Azores. They use the pelagic trawl technique and land other pelagic species such as mackerel, horse-mackerel or blue whiting. Herring is landed whole and frozen.
Stock status : The Northeast Atlantic (North Sea/Eastern English Channel) herring stock is not considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 0,79 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 7,84E-08 (100% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.

Orange, fresh grade {ES}| orange production, fresh grade | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Orange, fresh grade {ES}| orange production, fresh grade | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of orange, fresh grade (Navelina). Fresh grade oranges are meant for direct human consumption. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and for the year 2000: Yield_ (30 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 4187 m3/ha). The data are representative for orange production, fresh grade (Navelina), in Spain (Ribera Alta and Ribera Baixa) used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 300-65-135 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 3.6 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 14 kg a.i./ha and 74.7 kg/ha of horticultural oil.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of fresh grade oranges produced in Spain amounts to 20.5% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing fresh grade oranges produced in Spain or the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 2889660672 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (20 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Spain
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2000

- inputs have been regionalized for France / Europe when possible
_____________________________________________________________________________

This dataset represents green bell pepper production according to the Integrated Production standard in CH.

Yield: 80 t / ha.

Duration of one cropping cycle: 6 months.

Greenhouse production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:

 - bell pepper production, GLO, 2010 - 2010 (660610cf-3ee8-4c35-a3ce-4403d14d69c8)]

And an average amount of heating energy for the production and the seedling production is included. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). 
Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

activityName: Tomato, fresh grade {ES}| tomato production, fresh grade, in unheated greenhouse | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Tomato, fresh grade {ES}| tomato production, fresh grade, in unheated greenhouse | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of loose classic tomato for fresh consumption. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2006 - 2009: Yield_ (165 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 4748 m3/ha). The data are representative of loose classic tomatoes for fresh consumption, produced in Spain (Almeria) for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 798-506-1562 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 32.3 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of fresh grade tomatoes produced in Spain amounts to 10.4 % of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing fresh grade tomatoes produced in Spain for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.0 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 4255320576 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with harvest and transport to the farm gate. Storage is not included. 
The dataset includes all activities during a cycle, i.e. all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations include: soil cultivation, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Irrigation is included, as well as greenhouses infrastructures and energy consumption when relevant. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Spain
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2006
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Time period referring to the data source: 2006-2009. Based on expert opinion data is considered to be valid at least up to 2012.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Lamb, conventional, indoor production system, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : The inventory includes : all activites of a sheep farm, that is (1) all inputs as livestock (young animal), feeds, straw, water (watering and cleaning), fuels and energy as well as the transport to the farm; (2) the buildings and housings as well as infrastructure for milking; (3) the enteric emissions as well as emissions due to the effluent management
The temporal border of the inventory is 'from the birth of the animal to its leaving of the farm'.
This LCI include a water footprint calculation, according to the AGRIBALYSE 2 water scarcity assessment project. For more information about the method, see ADEME. MARTIN Edith (Quantis). 2018. Agribalyse ® 2  empreinte eau : rapport méthodologique. 
WARNING : only the direct water footprint of the animals is calculated here. The feedstuff doesn't contain a full water footprint evaluation. The user should be very careful about the interpretation of the results as the water footprint is not calculated on the full life cycle.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include vet products and cares, artificial insemination process, small cleaning material and all processes occuring outside of the farm (slaughtering, processing, conservation etc).
Refers to 1 kg (live weight) of lamb or 1 kg (live weight) of cull ewe or 1kg of wool
Allocation to the coproducts cull ewe, lamb and wool has been performed using the biophysical allocation approach.
  Lamb : 83.34% of weand lamb + 100% of lamb fattening + 98.8% of suckler ewe stages
  Wool : 2.32% of 1 year old ewe + 1.56% of ewe ready for lambing + 1.2% of suckler ewe stages
  Cull ewe : 97.68% 1 year old ewe + 98.44% of ewe ready for lambing
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg (live weight) of lamb or 1 kg (live weight) of cull ewe or 1kg of wool

activityName: Still wine, 75cl | Packaging System, N0, All, Glass bottle (green) 450g with cork stopper {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

N0, all Identification key for packaging system containing one or more element.
For more information, please refer to the methodological report  : Colombin, M., Audoye, P., Farrant, L., Allain, D., Anneraud, C., Bosque, F., Besnier, A., Bozec, A.(2024). Rapport méthodologique : volet emballages Agribalyse 3.2.

The inventory refers to a Glass bottle (green) 450g with cork stopper and the associated elements allowing to condition a volume of 75cl of Still wine.
Application to other cases: This inventory of packaging solution can only be used for products in sub-category Still wines (PACK_AGB) : refer to the report for more details. This inventory cannot be used to represent the same type of packaging for other products outside the sub-category Still wines (PACK_AGB) 

The data was produced from : weighing and collection from manufacturers.
The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

The packaging solutions developed as part of the PACK_AGB project have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html 

Overall data quality : DQR= 1,75; Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2; Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2; Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 2; Precision (P material) = 1; Precision (P processing) = 1
Time period: the data describing the packaging solution was collected over the period 2020-2022. 
The inventory is modelled for France. Packaging waste management is representative of packaging waste management in France. 
Property rights : OpenData, licence "Ecolab".  
Property data : ADEME

activityName: Orange, fresh grade {ZA}| orange production, fresh grade | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Orange, fresh grade {ZA}| orange production, fresh grade | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of orange, fresh grade. Fresh grade oranges are meant for direct human consumption. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year in 2015: Yield_ (38.11 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions. The data are representative for orange production, fresh grade, in South Africa used for the export market.

None

None

Production volume: 1645182976 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard. The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (33 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, and irrigation. Direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers (N-P2O5- K2O from mineral fertiliser input: 143-35-64 kg/ha*a ) and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for South Africa
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production

End date: 31/12/2022

activityName: Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Mint {RoW}| mint production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 8.000e+9 kg

IN: PV = 6.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.75

US: PV = 2.000e+9 kg; weight = 0.25

Yield of the global dataset = 28125 kg/ha, calculated as a weighted average of the regional Yield_s.

The comments below were part of the IN regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg mint. The average Yield_ from 1999 is 16.5 t/ha. The data are representative for mint production in India, Uttar Pradesh, used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 160-50-50 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.74 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing mint produced in India for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 8000000000 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing seedlings, i.e. seedlings from roots.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the clearing of the field (removing of mint plants). The dataset includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the field including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (4 years), and the clearing of the field. 
The establishment phase of the field includes seedlings nursery, soil cultivation, planting, herbicide use and irrigation.
The productive phase of the field includes machine operations, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting, transport on farm and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the field is cleared by removing the mint plants.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include drying.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Rest-of-World
Technology level: Current
Technology:

End date: 31/12/2022

activityName: White asparagus {FR}| white asparagus production | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: White asparagus {FR}| white asparagus production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of asparagus. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 4.2 t/ha. The data are representative for asparagus production in France. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 110-50-150 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 0.19 m3/ha of liquid manure and 0.15 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 5.66 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The share of asparagus produced in France amounts to 0.2% of the global production (tonnage produced in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing asparagus produced in France for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.3 (i.e. excellent quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 20012250 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing asparagus crown (seedlings).
Included activities end: This activity ends with the removal of asparagus roots after the productive phase (7 years). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the asparagus field including the establishment phase (2 years) per year of lifetime (9 years). 
The establishment phase of the asparagus field includes the nursery, manual planting, soil cultivation (plough), fertilisation (manure) and PE foil. 
The productive phase of the asparagus field includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, manual harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the field is cleared by removing the asparagus roots.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of asparagus crowns (seedlings), fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for France
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True

activityName: Onion {CN}| onion production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Onion {CN}| onion production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of onions The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2010 is 60 t/ha. The data are representative for onion production in China, Gansu province, used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 200-240-75 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 10.6 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of onions produced in China amounts to 9% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing onions produced in China for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.0 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 22684829696 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing seedlings, i.e. seedlings from roots.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of onions at farm gate. The dataset includes total diesel combusted in agricultural machinery, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. 
Statistical data from FAO used to assess land use change is incomplete for China. The original land use of 40.9% of annual cropland and 100% of perennial cropland transformed in the last 20 years is unknown. Land use change impacts may therefore be underestimated.

Field production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.

activityName: Coconut, dehusked {ID}| coconut production, dehusked | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Coconut, dehusked {ID}| coconut production, dehusked | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of coconut after manual dehusking at the farm. The co-product 'coconut husk' in included in the inventory. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2009 - 2012: Yield_ (6.1 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 2089 m3/ha). The data are representative for coconut production in Indonesia used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 45-69-30 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 1.69 m3/ha of liquid manure and 1.72 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 5.7 kg a.i./ha.

Coconut husk, is considered as a co-product of coconut production. Total coconut husk = 3.91 t/ha

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of coconut produced in Indonesia amounts to 23.6% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing coconut produced Indonesia for the export market. 

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 11269749760 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (60 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes limited machine operations such as fertiliser and pesticide application and irrigation. Most machine use and infrastructure are excluded as many activities (such as harvesting) are assumed to be manual work. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
 The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Indonesia
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Farm manure as an organic fertiliser is only accounted for in terms of direct field emissions; all pre-processes are included in the animal production systems.
Included activities end: The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvest, transport from field to regional processing centre (10 km) and drying of grains. Further, direct field emissions are included. The cultivation of green manure during winter before sowing beans is also included. This activity ends after drying of grains at the regional processing centre.

activityName: Saithe, Pollachius virens, NorthSea, Bottom Trawl, average, fresh, at landing {EU} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 4 boats fishing for fresh saithe in the North Sea (bottom trawl).

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant le lieu noir frais au chalut de fond en mer du Nord.
Fishery description : in France, fresh saithe is fished in the North Sea by 45 meters long ships. They are based in Boulogne-sur-Mer but can be brought to land in Lochinver (GB) and Hanstlhom (DK) too. They go out for 10 days fishing trips and spend between 250 and 280 days at sea per year. Their fishing area corresponds to the entire North Sea. They use the bottom trawl technique and land other benthic species such as ling or hake. Saithe is landed gutted and fresh (conversion ratio : 1,19).
Stock status : The North Sea saithe stock is not considered overfished : F/Fmsy = 0,78 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 3,51E-08 (95,5% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).

activityName: Lentil {CA-SK}| lentil production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2 in the original Ecoinvent LCI :
- Replacement of the negativ emission in the original LCI by 0
- Replacement of the transormation land use flow unspecified by the annual crop non-irrigated

This dataset represents the production of 1 tonne of dried lentil product with a dry matter content of 84% at minimum  during May-August, 2019, at 84924.57 ha lentil farms located in the Province of Saskatchewan, Canada. Farms have Yield_ of 1701.66 kg dried matter per ha for this crop cycle. The system boundaries include the production of all of crop inputs (e.g. seeds, fertilizers, crop protection products, and fuel). There is an estimated 0.49 kg of N fixation per tonne of lentils produced in this region that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. Irrigation is not included since it is rarely performed for lentils in this region. Sowing date for the crop is May, 2019 and harvesting date is August, 2020. Seeding rate is 0.06 kg/tonne of lentil production. Fertilizer applied contain nitrogen (as N) 5.19 kg/tonne, phosphate (as P2O5) 18.12 kg/tonne, potash (as K2O) 1.77 kg/tonne, sulfur (as S) 2.66 kg/tonne, and zinc (as Zn) 0.05 kg/tonne. Predominant crop protection applied contain active ingredients of Glyphosate 642.36 g/tonne, Ethalfluralin 76.88 g/tonne, and Sethoxydim 34.00 g/tonne. Machinery is used for tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, and burndown/desiccant application with total fuel consumption of 51.60 kg/tonne.

None

Production volume: 144758.796875 kg
Included activities start: Starting inputs for this activity include seed, fertilizer, crop protection products and fuel on the farm. This activity begins with soil preparation about 37 weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in 1st week of May and sowing of seeds started about 5 days after soil preparation.
Included activities end: This activity ends with lentil drying to <16% moisture at farm gate. Carbon and nitrogen emissions associated with above- and below-ground biomass are accounted for using the DNDC model. This model was also used to calculate a nitrogen fixation credit that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. For lentils in this region, the N credit was estimated to be 0.49 kg/t.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Saskatchewan
Technology level: Current
Technology: Production of lentil includes farm practices from tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, burndown/desiccant application, to drying.
Start date: 01/01/2017
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: April - May 2019; Harvesting date main crop: August, 2017-2019. The soil cultivation, sowing and harvesting dates are the data collected by the farmers. Total time from date of sowing to date of harvesting comes to 119 days. The data is collected for three crop cycles. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoinvent.
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Durum wheat grain, conventional, national average, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : (1) the processes of soil cultivation, sowing, weed control, fertilisation, pest and pathogen control, harvest; (2) the machines and shed or surface used to park them; (3) all inputs as seed, fertilizers (mineral and organic), active substances, water for irrigation, fuels as well as the transport to the farm; (4) the direct emissions of the fuel combustion, the abrasion of tyres and the direct emissions on the field.
The temporal border of the inventory is 'harvest to harvest'. Fertilizers (K, P and organic N) have been adjusted in order to account for the whole rotation.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include processes occuring after harvest as 'drying', 'sorting' or 'storing', even if they happen on farm.
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of fresh matter of durum wheat (15% moisture), conventional production. 
Raw datas comes from:The data is based on literature and statistical data as well as expert judgements. 
Transformation has been performed (weightening and assignments of the flows as well as calculation of direct field emissions).
PEF  Overall data quality : 
Technological representativeness (TeR) = 2 : Good
Geographical representativeness (GR) = 2 : Good
Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 3 : Fair
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 2 : Good
Final note = 2,25 : Good data quality level
Yield: 4759.0 kg
Coproducts: Straw. Total straw per hectare: 3604 kg DM/ha. The straw is harvested on 16% of the surfaces (i.e. straw valorized = 577 kg DM/ha).. Allocation: No allocation has been performed as the price of straw is not known..

activityName: Lentils, dry, at farm (WFLDB)
comment:
Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of dry lentils at farm (moisture content 14%). The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year (1710 kg/ha) produced under non-irrigated conditions. The dataset represents a mix of red and green lentils with a ratio of 75/25 red/green based on registered sales rates.

Allocation: No allocation

System boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes inputs of fertilisers, pesticides, and seeds, as well as field work processes and the associated diesel combusted in agricultural machinery. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser and pesticide use) and land use change are included. After harvesting, lentils are transferred to a storage bin close to the farm, where they are mechanically dried by aeriation to maintain safe storage. Lentil straw has no economic value, and is not harvested, therefore no co-product or residue treatment is accounted for.

Data quality rating: 1.2 (i.e. excellent quality)

Geography: The dataset describes the production of lentils in Saskatchewan and Alberta provinces in Canada

Technology: Conventional production

Time: 2012-2017

Data sources:
1. (S&T)2 Consultants (2017) Carbon Footprint for Canadian lentils. Canadian Roundtable on Sustainable Crops
2. ttps://albertapulse.com/lentil-harvesting/

activityName: Common Sole, Solea solea, BBiscay, Trammel Net, average, at landing {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
Production-weighted average activity of 11 boats fishing for sole in the Bay of Biscay (trammel net)

Translated name : Activité annuelle moyenne des navires ciblant la sole au filet trémail dans le Golfe de Gascogne.
Fishery description : In France, gillneters fishing for sole in the Bay of Biscay are 12 to 20 meters long ships. They are disseminated all along the French Atlantic coast, from Le Guilvinec to Bayonne. They go out for a 10 hours trip and spend approximately 200 days at sea per year. Their fishing area is off the Bay of Biscay coasts. They use the trammel net technique and fish other species such as anglerfishes. Sole is generally landed gutted and fresh (conversion ratio : 1,04) in the ships' french home ports.
Stock status : The Bay of Biscay sole stock is considered slightly overfished : F/Fmsy = 1,09 (ICES 2017 data ; overfished if F/Fmsy >1). 
Pressure on stocks indicator : 4,23E-06 (60,0% of catch taken into account). This indicator is based on scientific publications and was applied to the ICV Pêche project's fisheries. For more details, please see the methodological handbook available on ADEME website.
Included processes : 
	Inventory includes : use of resources and amount of emissions during fishing and storage operations as well as construction, maintenance and end-of-life of fishing boat and gears. 
	Inventory excludes : impacts caused by life on board and harbour activities including landing operations. 
Remark: AGRIBALYSE (based on the project AGRIBALYSE 2.0 LCI of French fisheries).
Refers to : Average annual activity of boats fishing for sole in the Bay of Biscay (trammel net)
Geography : France.
Version : 1.0.

activityName: Linseed {RoW}| linseed production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Linseed {RoW}| linseed production | Cut-off, U

This dataset is a weighted average of the regional datasets, with weights based on production volume of the reference product.  Detailed comments and sources about the exchanges can be found in the regional datasets.

The geographicalCorrelation score of every pedigree matrix of was changed to '5'.

Sum of regional production volumes: 8.329e+8 kg

CA: PV = 5.526e+8 kg; weight = 0.6635

RU: PV = 2.803e+8 kg; weight = 0.3365

The comments below were part of the CA regional dataset.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of linseed grains. The average Yield_ from 2003-2004 is 1.3 t/ha at standard water content required for storage (10%). The data are representative for linseed production in western Canada used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-10-0 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 4 m3/ha of liquid manure and 3 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 1.69 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of linseed grains produced in Canada amounts to 59% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing linseed grains produced in Canada for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 1231968256 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of grains at farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include a) emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production and b) drying due to lack of data.
Energy values: Undefined

Technology level: Current

Apricot {FR}| apricot production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Apricot {FR}| apricot production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of apricots. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 20 t/ha. The data are representative for apricots production in France used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-20-75 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 1 m3/ha of liquid manure and 1 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 5.6 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of apricots produced in France amounts to 19% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing apricots produced in France for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.8 (i.e. very good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 171400752 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (20 years, 500 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.

Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers (mineral and organic) and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for France
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Coffee, green bean {IN}| coffee green bean production, arabica | Cut-off, U - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Coffee, green bean {IN}| coffee green bean production, arabica | Cut-off, U
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of green coffee beans (Arabica). Arabica is a variety of coffee that has a sweeter, softer taste, with tones of sugar, fruit, and berries. It has a higher acidity but twice less caffeine compared to Robusta beans, and is generally considered to be of higher quality compared to Robusta. Arabica is mostly grown in Latin America and India. The reference flow is the average Yield_ per ha and year, from 2012 - 2014: Yield_ (725 kg/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 352 m3/ha). The data are representative for Arabica green coffee beans production in India (Karnataka state) used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 900-0-0 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.15 kg a.i./ha and 3.7 kg/ha of neem oil.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of coffee produced in India amounts to 3.4% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing Arabica green coffee beans produced in India for the export market. 

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.2 (i.e. good quality)

This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 91972128 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with the nursery producing fruit tree seedlings, i.e.grafted young trees to be planted.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard (rooting up the trees). The dataset includes all activities during a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (20 years), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, installation of trellis system (posts and wires) and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (mulching, mowing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees.
 The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. Green coffee beans are sun-dried.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.

Field production.

The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:

http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577

Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

None

This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg mint. The average Yield_ from 1999 is 16.5 t/ha. The data are representative for mint production in India, Uttar Pradesh, used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 160-50-50 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.74 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing mint produced in India for the export market.

The establishment phase of the field includes seedlings nursery, soil cultivation, planting, herbicide use and irrigation.
The productive phase of the field includes machine operations, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation, fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting, transport on farm and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the field is cleared by removing the mint plants.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include drying.

activityName: Corrugated board box {RER}| production | Cut-off, S - Copied from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Corrugated board box {RER}| corrugated board box production | Cut-off, S

Corrugated Board is manufactured from several specially conditioned layers of recycled or virgin papers, with the Fluting Medium being the middle layer and Linerboard used for the outside layers. Reels of Fluting Medium and Linerboard are fed into a machine which is called a Corrugator (FEFCO, 2018). In integrated plants such as the ones represented here, the finished board is further folded into boxes.

https://db3.ecoinvent.org/images/fb7c96f2-1933-4a81-a33a-515d0a5fb151 [Image URL, right click copy paste to a browser to view]

The data on corrugated board production are based on 389 plants (mostly integrated plants with corrugated board and box production on the same site) in Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the United Kingdom. Together they produced 12,100,000 tonnes saleable product, which is 54% of the total annual production of corrugated board products in Europe. Each of the production sites produces on average 31.100 tonnes of corrugated sheets, ranging from 5.000  500.000 tonnes each. Reference(s): https://www.fefco.org/sites/default/files/documents/LCA%20Report%202019_revised_%20p%2037.pdf, accessed September 2022.

For this dataset the European average of recycled and virgin paper inputs (wellenstoff, semichemical fluting, kraftliner, testliner) was used.

The following air emissions were reported in the study: CO2 (fossil), CO, NOx (as NO2), SOx (as SO2), particulates (all sizes).

For a more complete air emission profile, additional air emissions (beyond the ones listed above) were added for the combustion of the external fuels and internal using LCI datasets for combustion of different fuels as proxy. The air emissions were calculated based on the mix of the external fuels in the study and more information about the fuel mix and the proxy are provided under "Extrapolations".

The production volume is valid for the year 2018. Inventory data were collected for the year 2018.

Production volume: 24306999296 kg
Included activities start: The process starts as reels of Fluting Medium and Linerboard are fed into a machine called a Corrugator.
Included activities end: This activity ends with folded corrugated board boxes ready for delivery.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Europe
Technology level: Current
Technology: Average of present used technology

The Fluting Medium paper is conditioned with heat and steam and fed between large corrugating rolls that give the paper its fluted shape in the Single Facer. Starch is applied to the tips of the flutes on one side and the inner liner is glued to the fluting. The corrugated fluting medium with liner attached to it is called single face web and travels along the machine towards the Double Backer where the single face web meets the outer liner and forms corrugated board. A number of layers of single faced web may be built up to produce double and triple wall corrugated board. The corrugated board is slit into the required widths and cut into sheets which are then stacked or palletised. The final stage of the process consists of printing and then slotting, folding and gluing the corrugated board to manufacture a corrugated box.
Start date: 01/01/2018
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

activityName: Carrot {NL}| carrot production | Cut-off, U - Adapted from Ecoinvent U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.
original ecoinvent name: Carrot {NL}| carrot production | Cut-off, U

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of carrots. The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 57 t/ha. The data are representative for carrot production in the Netherlands. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 140-49-220 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 6.03 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of carrots produced in the Netherlands amounts to 19% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing carrots produced in the Netherlands for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 2.7 (i.e. good quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Production volume: 508750016 kg
Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of the carrots and their transport to the farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included.The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production.  Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
Energy values: Undefined
Geography: The inventory is modelled for Netherlands
Technology level: Current
Technology: Conventional production
Start date: 01/01/2009
End date: 31/12/2022
Is data valid for entire period: True
Time period: 
Macro-economic scenario name: Business-as-Usual

Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 14.85 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of onions produced in the Netherlands amounts to 20% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing onions produced in the Netherlands for the export market.

The dataset includes total diesel combusted in agricultural machinery, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.

activityName: Sheep milk, conventional, Roquefort system, at farm gate {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
Included processes: The inventory includes : The inventory includes : all activites of a sheep farm, that is (1) all inputs as livestock (young animal), feeds, straw, water (watering and cleaning), fuels and energy as well as the transport to the farm; (2) the buildings and housings as well as infrastructure for milking; (3) the enteric emissions as well as emissions due to the effluent management
The temporal border of the inventory is 1 year of production
This LCI include a water footprint calculation, according to the AGRIBALYSE 2 water scarcity assessment project. For more information about the method, see ADEME. MARTIN Edith (Quantis). 2018. Agribalyse ® 2  empreinte eau : rapport méthodologique. 
WARNING : only the direct water footprint of the animals is calculated here. The feedstuff doesn't contain a full water footprint evaluation. The user should be very careful about the interpretation of the results as the water footprint is not calculated on the full life cycle.
Cut-off rule, exclusion : The inventory does not include vet products and cares, artificial insemination process, small cleaning material and all processes occuring outside of the farm (slaughtering, processing, conservation etc).
Refers to 1 kg of FPC sheep milk or 1kg of wool or 1 kg (live weight) of cull ewe or 1 kg (live weight) of lamb
Allocation to the coproducts milk, cull ewe, lamb and wool has been performed using the biophysical allocation approach.
  Lamb : 100% of weaned lamb + 9.28% of diary ewe
  Wool : 1.36% of 1 year old ewe + 2.01% of diary ewe
  Cull ewe : 98.64% of 1 year old ewe
  Milk : 88.71 of diary ewe
Remark: Functional unit:1 kg of FPC sheep milk or 1kg of wool or 1 kg (live weight) of cull ewe or 1 kg (live weight) of lamb
Coproducts: 432.0 Sold lamb (weight 14 kg), undefined kg  Wool, 157681.0 kg  Milk, undefined kg  Wool, 86.0 Cast dairy ewe (weight 75 kg)
Raw datas comes from:The data is based on literature and statistical data as well as expert judgements. Transformation have been performed (weightening and assignments of the flows as well as calculation of direct field emissions).
PEF  Overall data quality : 
Technological representativeness (TeR) = 4 : Poor
Geographical representativeness (GR) = 1 : Very good
Time-related representativeness (TiR) = 1 : Very good
Precision / uncertainty (P) = 3 : Fair
Final note = 2,25 : Good data quality level
undefined
Dataset was generated by MEANS-InOut software.
Models used : [CH4 enteric, INRA Feeding System for Ruminants, tier 3; NOx - EMEP 2019, tier 1; N2O - IPCC 2019, tier 2;  N - AGRIBALYSE 2015; N2O - IPCC 2006, tier 2; Water consumed and lost by animals; CH4 manure - IPCC 2019, tier 2; NH3 - EMEP 2019, tier 2; ]
MEANS id : Scenario #5781
Technology: Conventional production -  production mode: Conventional production, specialized dairy sheep farm, conventional production based on forage grown on farm, quite intensive small farm. -
Time period: Inventory data based on the period : 2005-2009
Version: 0.0
Energy values: Net values
Production volume: Production volume : 166000 metric tons
Source file: Dairy Sheep - conven_MEANS#5781-Ecoinvent 3.8 - AGB 3.1.1.xml

activityName: Sunflower, at farm {GLO} - Adapted from WFLDB U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. 
This dataset has been adapted for Agribalyse 3.2.
- Background Ecoinvent data have been updated to Ecoinvent 3.9.1
_________________________________
This dataset represents the global average for Sunflower, at farm. It is calculated as weighted average of the following countries, based on their respective export shares according to FAOSTAT data for 2010:
 - Hungary: 18%
 - France: 11%
 - Ukraine: 8%
 - Russia: 0.26%
These countries together represent 40% of global export. 
All farming activities documented in the respective national datasets are included. No transportation to the marketplace is considered.
The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Sunflower, at standard water content required for storage of 10%.

Data quality rating (DQR) = 2.3 (i.e. good quality)

comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024. - supporting LCI (based on the project ECOALIM).
Included processes: The inventory includes the processes of crop cultivation, transport of fresh matter from farm to storage (9 km by tractor, 35 km by truck), storage, and drying when necessary.
Remark: Generic data for all types of French crop are used for transport, based on Arvalis-Institut du Végétal expertise. Drying, when necessary, is expressed as quantity of liters discharged from the grain. This quantity is calculated based on initial moisture and required final moisture.

activityName: Milk, other than from cow, 1000g | Packaging System, N0, All, HDPE bottle {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

N0, all Identification key for packaging system containing one or more element.
For more information, please refer to the methodological report  : Colombin, M., Audoye, P., Farrant, L., Allain, D., Anneraud, C., Bosque, F., Besnier, A., Bozec, A.(2024). Rapport méthodologique : volet emballages Agribalyse 3.2.

The inventory refers to a PEHD bottle and the associated elements allowing to condition a total weight of 1000 g of liquid milk.  
This inventory of packaging solution can only be used for products in sub-category "Milk and milk products" (PACK_AGB) : refer to the report for more details. 

The packaging solution describes a PEHD 1L bottle with aluminium lid, PEHD stopper and paper label.
The data was produced from study of packaging on the French market (supermarket reference) and data collection from manufacturers. 
The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. ***Application of CCF, rate of virgin and recycled materials corresponding to the FR scenario (2022) 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE)

The packaging solutions developed as part of the PACK_AGB project have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html

Adaptation in AGB 3.3 to be a better proxy for mustard (the main proportion of the mustard seeds comes from canada, and rape seed and mustard is quiet similar in term of cultures): 
- mustard culture is not a GMO and most of the time the herbicide is not glufosinate, the replacement of "glufosinate" by "pesticide unspecified" has been done (as input of the technosphere and emission to soil)

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of rapeseed, at standard water content required for storage (8%). The average Yield_ from 2009 - 2012 is 1.9 t/ha. Data are representative for rapeseed production in western Canada, that represents 80% of fields in Canada, used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 85-20-0 kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 3.27 m3/ha of liquid manure and 2.33 t/ha of solid manure. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 1.03 kg a.i./ha.

The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of rapeseed produced in Canada amounts to 44% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing rapeseed produced in Canada for the export market.

PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.3 (i.e. excellent quality). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

Included activities start: This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.
Included activities end: This activity ends with the harvest of grains and their transport to the farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation (a mixture of no tillage and minimum tillage), sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, grain drying, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered. The dataset doesn't include a) emissions from manure storage because these are within the system boundary of animal production and b) irrigation because rapeseed is normally not irrigated in western Canada.

activityName: Fresh sausages, 330g | Packaging System, N0, All, PP Tray with Lid {FR} U
comment:
AGRIBALYSE v3.2 dataset, 2024.

N0, all Identification key for packaging system containing one or more element.
For more information, please refer to the methodological report  : Colombin, M., Audoye, P., Farrant, L., Allain, D., Anneraud, C., Bosque, F., Besnier, A., Bozec, A.(2024). Rapport méthodologique : volet emballages Agribalyse 3.2.

The inventory refers to a "PP tray" and the associated elements allowing to condition a weight of 330g of fresh sausages. 
Application to other cases: This inventory of packaging solution can only be used for products in sub-category "Fresh sausages" (PACK_AGB) : refer to the report for more details. This inventory cannot be used to represent the same type of packaging for other products outside the sub-category "Fresh sausages" (PACK_AGB).

The data was produced from study of packaging on the French market (supermarket reference), weighing of two references and CTCPA packaging expertise.
Two references were weighed to best represent the French market. They are marketed both under own brand and under private label.
The weight of 330g of product used was obtained by averaging two references of 330g and 330g. The weight of the packaging corresponds to the average of the weighed packaging.

The inventory includes : (1) production of packaging materials***, (2) manufacture and finishing of packaging components, (3) intermediate transport from the production of materials to the packaging site, and (4) the end-of-life management of packaging*** as it takes place in France. ***Application of CCF, rate of virgin and recycled materials corresponding to the FR scenario (2022) 
The inventory does not include distribution transport (integrated into the next stage at distribution in AGRIBALYSE).

The packaging solutions developed as part of the PACK_AGB project have not been developed for use in comparative LCAs of packaging solutions: if this is your purpose, we recommend that you follow the ADEME reference framework on comparative comparative LCA between different packaging solutions: https://librairie.ademe.fr/dechets-economie-circulaire/5309-cadre-de-reference-acv-comparatives-entre-differentes-solutions-d-emballages.html .
